{"Status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "Hamilton's Object - a clumpy galaxy straddling the gravitational caustic of a galaxy cluster: constraints on dark matter clumping", "authors": ["Griffiths, Richard E.", "Rudisel, Mitchell", "Wagner, Jenny", "Hamilton, Timothy", "Huang, Po-Chieh", "Villforth, Carolin"], "author_address": ["AA(Department of Physics &amp; Astronomy, University of Hawaii at Hilo, 200 W. Kawili St, Hilo, HI 96720, USA; Department of Physics, Carnegie Mellon University, 5000 Forbes Ave., Pittsburgh, PA 15213, USA), AB(Department of Physics &amp; Astronomy, University of Hawaii at Hilo, 200 W. Kawili St, Hilo, HI 96720, USA), AC(Zentrum f\u00fcr Astronomie, Astronomisches Rechen-Institut, Universit\u00e4t Heidelberg, M\u00f6nchhofstr. 12-14, D-69120 Heidelberg, Germany), AD(Department of Natural Sciences, Shawnee State University, 940 Second Street, Portsmouth, OH 45662, USA), AE(Department of Physics &amp; Astronomy, University of Hawaii at Hilo, 200 W. Kawili St, Hilo, HI 96720, USA; Dept. of Physics, Chung Yuan Christian University, 200 Chung Pei Road, Chung Li District, Taoyuan City, Taiwan 32023, R.O.C), AF(Department of Physics, University of Bath, Claverton Down, Bath BA2 7AY, UK)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "506", "publication_year": "2021/09/1", "start_page": "1595", "end_page": "1608", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "galaxies: clusters: general", "dark matter", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2021MNRAS.506.1595G", "abstract": "We report the discovery of a 'folded' gravitationally lensed image, 'Hamilton's Object', found in a HST image of the field near the active galactic nucleus SDSS J223010.47-081017.8 (which has redshift 0.62). The lensed images are sourced by a galaxy at a spectroscopic redshift of 0.8200 \u00b1 0.0005 and form a fold configuration on a caustic caused by a foreground galaxy cluster at a photometric redshift of 0.526 \u00b1 0.018 seen in the corresponding Pan-STARRS PS1 image and marginally detected as a faint ROSAT All-Sky Survey X-ray source. The lensed images exhibit properties similar to those of other 'folds' where the source galaxy falls very close to or straddles the caustic of a galaxy cluster. The folded images are stretched in a direction roughly orthogonal to the critical curve, but the configuration is that of a tangential cusp. Guided by morphological features, published simulations and similar 'fold' observations in the literature, we identify a third or 'counter'-image, confirmed by spectroscopy. Because the fold-configuration shows highly distinctive surface brightness features, follow-up observations of microlensing or detailed investigations of the individual surface brightness features at higher resolution can further shed light on kpc-scale dark matter properties. We determine the local lens properties at the positions of the multiple images according to the observation-based lens reconstruction of Wagner. The analysis is in accordance with a mass density which hardly varies on an arcsecond scale (6 kpc) over the areas covered by the multiple images.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stab1375", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:2105.04562", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "2"}, "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2021MNRAS.506.1595G", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n    <div        <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103418 id=\"269103418\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery of a \u2018folded\u2019 gravitationally lensed image, \u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019, found in a <em>HST</em> image of the field near the active galactic nucleus SDSS J223010.47-081017.8 (which has redshift 0.62). The lensed images are sourced by a galaxy at a spectroscopic redshift of 0.8200\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0005 and form a fold configuration on a caustic caused by a foreground galaxy cluster at a photometric redshift of 0.526\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.018 seen in the corresponding Pan-STARRS PS1 image and marginally detected as a faint <em>ROSAT</em> All-Sky Survey X-ray source. The lensed images exhibit properties similar to those of other \u2018folds\u2019 where the source galaxy falls very close to or straddles the caustic of a galaxy cluster. The folded images are stretched in a direction roughly orthogonal to the critical curve, but the configuration is that of a tangential cusp. Guided by morphological features, published simulations and similar \u2018fold\u2019 observations in the literature, we identify a third or \u2018counter\u2019-image, confirmed by spectroscopy. Because the fold-configuration shows highly distinctive surface brightness features, follow-up observations of microlensing or detailed investigations of the individual surface brightness features at higher resolution can further shed light on kpc-scale dark matter properties. We determine the local lens properties at the positions of the multiple images according to the observation-based lens reconstruction of Wagner. The analysis is in accordance with a mass density which hardly varies on an arcsecond scale (6\u00a0kpc) over the areas covered by the multiple images.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103420 id=\"269103420\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Light of all wavelengths responds to the curvature of spacetime, which in turn depends on matter and energy content. One outcome of this response is gravitational lensing (for an introduction, see Kochanek, Schneider &amp; Wambsganss (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)), and the study of extragalactic gravitationally lensed objects has become a very fruitful field of research over the past few decades. These studies started with the startling discovery of multiply imaged quasars (Walsh, Carswell\u00a0&amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>), and the general subject of extragalactic lensing has since diversified into a number of extremely active and productive areas, including lensing by large-scale structures, e.g. the Kilo-degree Survey (Tr\u00f6ster et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>) and the Dark Energy Survey (To et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>); clusters of galaxies (Soucail et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>; Kneib &amp; Natarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; the Cluster Lensing and Supernova Survey with Hubble (CLASH; Merten et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>); and the Reionization Lensing Cluster Survey (RELICS; Coe et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and individual galaxies: measurement of H<sub>0</sub> via time-delay cosmography (e.g. Millon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Over the last decade, the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> has been used to determine the mass distribution in clusters of galaxies via the characterization of the multiple lensed systems found in each of the massive clusters studied (these large projects have included the Hubble Frontier Fields: Lotz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; the CLASH survey; and the Beyond Ultra-Deep Frontier Fields and Legacy Observations survey: Steinhardt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Lens reconstruction algorithms have been used to infer the masses and other properties of these clusters: see Meneghetti et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for an overview and a benchmark of common approaches. The resulting masses have been compared with the masses inferred from X-ray observations to study the central parts of the cluster and its relaxation state. Weak gravitational lensing reconstructions in the outer cluster regions complete the reconstruction of the mass-density profile of a galaxy cluster. Constraints on the properties of dark matter (DM) afforded by gravitational lensing have been reviewed by Massey, Kitching\u00a0&amp; Richard (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper describes a strong gravitational-lensing configuration, \u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019, consisting of two resolved images of a clumpy spiral background galaxy in a fold configuration and a third resolved image of the same spiral galaxy, which together create a tangential cusp configuration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The importance of this discovery is in the potential for constraining small-scale DM properties using the highly resolved multiple image configuration straddling the critical curve. Analysis of the individual features observed in the multiple images or the detection of microlensing events on top of the galaxy-cluster-scale magnification effect make such fold configurations ideal probes of DM properties. Future goals could include the investigation of the abundance and distribution of possible compact halo objects or ultralight axion DM.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103424 id=\"269103424\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A complex of folded, distorted, and stretched gravitationally lensed images (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) has been discovered in a <em>HST</em> WFC3 image (P.I. Villforth, Program GO 13305) of the field around the active galactic nucleus (AGN) SDSS J223010.47-081017.8, an AGN possibly identified with the marginally detected <em>ROSAT</em> All Sky Survey source RASS 1RXS J223011.3-081024 (from Anderson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, listed as RASS 6135 in Villforth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The complex lensed images are surrounded by a cluster of galaxies evident in the Pan-STARRS PS1 images archived at the Hubble Legacy Archive (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://hla.stsci.edu\" target=\"_blank\">https://hla.stsci.edu</a>), and also in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). The SDSS cluster is catalogued as Red Mapper Cluster RM J223013.1-080853.1 (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/\" target=\"_blank\">http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/</a>). redMaPPer is an optical cluster finder based on the detection of spatial overdensities of red sequence galaxies (Wechsler et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Rykoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, McClintock et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). The cluster also appears in the Wavelet Z Photometric catalogue (q.v.: Aguena et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>) in which overdensities are found based on redshifts rather than colours.</p>                        <a id=\"269103426\" scrollto-destination=\"269103426\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=3vsuUGSVOzORuRqmxHMMNr3D0BLYaIl8nDOEuow0cImZ8817MHgdGrJGUBDWWCM7h3J3mpN8s6y2qWSbH-sU0w6qay4jL3gmvhHKBCtdO4L2UWurOkm8Tv7p9PfCxTDXyk-obl4fmSuf2Sy3R5WA1er1RJPCH6M39uzCm4wXQcSRrkC8hTSc2RU3P1af2IfPogP6qKpOkY9c9~E620yCU9LijHRd6r1-BlCJbDElanQsJJYY-iD8W7DFt1QYTCmh9fmeLS4wJ4glFVndF8mM3~AplwGWAALTGSTKAVsLmHWxHeyHlmLfBHqaJ~wRREu5lQL5gfCLWsP0Koooub4TJw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019: the HST WFC3 H-band image (3 \u00d7 700\u2009s). The lensed images are encircled. The halfway point between the two brightest lensed image components is at RA 22h30m9s.7, Dec. \u221208o09\u203240\u2033 (J2000). The scale bar is 10 arc secs.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103426/stab1375fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103426\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=I8bBzU0apJHEU6SgkI8dz9EKowCwm6uPiR4UePmCFaJKFkic0FNAe9CqfRylsIjoO2o9fHWr5oLFcQlBjLFJuNfUKINaj6FVMF9PX0G18XH-rBWQEJGVy1zqzirFYNMMfNz5peY199B8ozF~u~W3vt90t9Lz~uQwkkTHggAz03OrT09ix7rEQ6KW5sv-2Xzy8itb82n~x~u7fiYunzYssoiJrPcfVtohDfN-KrzFIIkCiBV0SHeY2anvKkBohWyFqyCxtLHj3Xi8DeuPOx5jSsTdlgI-RLYpX95J~zp7YMVRgPlhU3rXYGsgtzZ-gGQ7ZjpR6jJPJPPPQRef1kU6yg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103426&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019: the <em>HST</em> WFC3 H-band image (3 \u00d7 700\u2009s). The lensed images are encircled. The halfway point between the two brightest lensed image components is at RA 22<sup>h</sup>30<sup>m</sup>9<sup>s</sup>.7, Dec. \u221208<sup>o</sup>09\u203240\u2033 (J2000). The scale bar is 10 arc secs.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=3vsuUGSVOzORuRqmxHMMNr3D0BLYaIl8nDOEuow0cImZ8817MHgdGrJGUBDWWCM7h3J3mpN8s6y2qWSbH-sU0w6qay4jL3gmvhHKBCtdO4L2UWurOkm8Tv7p9PfCxTDXyk-obl4fmSuf2Sy3R5WA1er1RJPCH6M39uzCm4wXQcSRrkC8hTSc2RU3P1af2IfPogP6qKpOkY9c9~E620yCU9LijHRd6r1-BlCJbDElanQsJJYY-iD8W7DFt1QYTCmh9fmeLS4wJ4glFVndF8mM3~AplwGWAALTGSTKAVsLmHWxHeyHlmLfBHqaJ~wRREu5lQL5gfCLWsP0Koooub4TJw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019: the HST WFC3 H-band image (3 \u00d7 700\u2009s). The scale bar is 10 arc secs.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103426/stab1375fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103426\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=I8bBzU0apJHEU6SgkI8dz9EKowCwm6uPiR4UePmCFaJKFkic0FNAe9CqfRylsIjoO2o9fHWr5oLFcQlBjLFJuNfUKINaj6FVMF9PX0G18XH-rBWQEJGVy1zqzirFYNMMfNz5peY199B8ozF~u~W3vt90t9Lz~uQwkkTHggAz03OrT09ix7rEQ6KW5sv-2Xzy8itb82n~x~u7fiYunzYssoiJrPcfVtohDfN-KrzFIIkCiBV0SHeY2anvKkBohWyFqyCxtLHj3Xi8DeuPOx5jSsTdlgI-RLYpX95J~zp7YMVRgPlhU3rXYGsgtzZ-gGQ7ZjpR6jJPJPPPQRef1kU6yg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103426&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019: the <em>HST</em> WFC3 H-band image (3 \u00d7 700\u2009s). The lensed images are encircled. The halfway point between the two brightest lensed image components is at RA 22<sup>h</sup>30<sup>m</sup>9<sup>s</sup>.7, Dec. \u221208<sup>o</sup>09\u203240\u2033 (J2000). The scale bar is 10 arc secs.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103427 id=\"269103427\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 X-ray detection of the galaxy cluster</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Thus far, there have been no pointed (or slew-survey) x-ray observations of the cluster using XMM-Newton or the Chandra X-ray Observatory. But, as well as <em>ROSAT</em> detection of the nearby AGN, the cluster was marginally detected in the <em>ROSAT</em> All Sky Survey (RASS) as x-ray source 1RXS \u00a0J222956.9-080823 (Voges et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) with x-ray countrate 3.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.7\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22122</sup> counts s<sup>\u22121</sup> corresponding to a flux of 3.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221213</sup> ergs cm<sup>\u22122</sup> s<sup>\u22121</sup> (0.1\u20132.4 kev). The RASS Faint Source Catalogue (RASSFSC) is included in the second <em>ROSAT</em> All-Sky Survey Catalogue (2RXS: Boller et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) but the 2RXS has only one source in the vicinity of the AGN and the cluster, a source which is assigned a 43\u00a0per\u2009cent probability of extension, with extremely few x-ray counts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The cluster x-ray source was too faint to be included in the <em>ROSAT</em>-ESO Flux-Limited X-ray Galaxy Cluster Survey (REFLEX; B\u00f6hringer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) or in REFLEX II (Chon\u00a0&amp; B\u00f6hringer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), even though those papers addressed clusters in the appropriate redshift range.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Likewise, the cluster is not included in the Master Catalogue of X-ray Selected Clusters (Piffaretti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). With a photometric redshift for the cluster of 0.526\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.018 (redMaPPerClusters \u2013 from SDSS DR8: NASA Extragalactic Database (NED) RM\u00a0J223013.1-080853.1), the X-ray luminosity (taking the 1XRS cluster source flux) is 3.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>44</sup> ergs s<sup>\u22121</sup> (0.5\u20132.4\u00a0keV). Using the correlation between cluster mass and x-ray luminosity found by Stanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), this luminosity would imply an approximate mass of 5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, in the mid-range for clusters.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103434 id=\"269103434\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Optical images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The discovery image of \u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019 in the <em>HST</em> WFC3 H-band is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and the F606W image in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, where the latter image shows structure (superstarburst regions) within 0.2 arcsec to the west of the nuclear bulge. The overall object shows a (roughly north-south) mirror symmetry, with two brighter component images (nuclear bulges), one in each half, and three (split) linear features, spanning a total of about 4 by 6 arcsec. The two brightest central (nuclear bulge) images have F606W magnitudes of \u2243 24 from SExtractor in the <em>HST</em> archive, and each has slightly arced and stretched images to both the east and west. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the Sextractor magnitudes of the central nuclear bulge objects in the <em>HST</em> filters.</p>                        <a id=\"269103439\" scrollto-destination=\"269103439\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=fPsU3QjvuBEX3R4xGHrLJseMH1m11fp2IkCDRqbNFGmYUFE1gFZbPtRzsgVO3ZNk72auXAZ4wttT2o3a6PHb1rH6m2E-9LG2zR4SLZq~jy6mLPbwOJ5wspBut8fH067TN2UNoQJUyArmnRVmSXCp1mQyK~dolPqDR6~r2Q~tInOaLUenjjmO~1Z9W-l7AdxpCpexb7yFwKj61voNhtd7ISGetNzkwG2Vyz84uciCWPZh1Qfe3NvQoIsY32dpjBG6Kp207FmJekHYHSDTCAP9PpGrSzoKOj~bLCRhPOzBKvjY1CetE8o-LQXOodkZWQV84V7w9EHctnd9qdbXn31LvA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The HST ACS/F606W image (3600\u00a0s) showing folded images A and B and third or counterimage C (see Section\u00a03.2). These features are seen more clearly in Figs\u00a07 and\u00a012. The overall frame size is 18\u00a0\u00d7\u00a025 arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103439/stab1375fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103439\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=vdMyYtEppMd68fv-tSwxW0C1F60aD9zJTVH51k~OzEtsmnkrLU09x8Dh7Bdl78W-UobIyiIEKrUkzy-w2V6xATIjfiJDtcGB1cRvfoMBNuH5TsQLO5YYQXi6yzXqAfbhLbHmLmn60kEiSPaqZH4MSeFnTs676IBdmcY62q8I-vlOJku9G5sHNpPNpnubol5Id8NH3vD1y6iI6mY3ISWYawwfnnfObKQpyNBjDKAXmeJTFtk7PyFDyfD7VQGjhz6JPDa-qycV8aebH9R6nF9Hl7VH7SlqqBS6OBT1DQIYSDqgcZNn2~2j7lNBTKqjpgT2nsAV6lj085v4mp4zWNIf9g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103439&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>HST</em> ACS/F606W image (3600\u00a0s) showing folded images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> and third or counterimage <em>C</em> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.2</a>). The nuclear bulges are A1, B1, C1, and the surface brightness features of C are labelled 2\u20137, with corresponding features in fold images A and B.        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.17\u00a0</td><td>22.46\u00a0</td><td>21.55\u00a0</td><td>21.29\u00a0</td><td>21.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>B</em>\u00a0</td><td>22.80\u00a0</td><td>22.20\u00a0</td><td>21.22\u00a0</td><td>20.93\u00a0</td><td>20.86\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>C</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.69\u00a0</td><td>23.30\u00a0</td><td>22.13\u00a0</td><td>21.87\u00a0</td><td>21.57\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F606W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F814W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F110W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F140W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F160W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.17\u00a0</td><td>22.46\u00a0</td><td>21.55\u00a0</td><td>21.29\u00a0</td><td>21.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>B</em>\u00a0</td><td>22.80\u00a0</td><td>22.20\u00a0</td><td>21.22\u00a0</td><td>20.93\u00a0</td><td>20.86\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>C</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.69\u00a0</td><td>23.30\u00a0</td><td>22.13\u00a0</td><td>21.87\u00a0</td><td>21.57\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/269103446\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">There is a very high degree of symmetry about a line running through the centre of the whole lensed image at a position angle of about 100 deg (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The original <em>HST</em> WFC3 image (with exposure of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0700\u2009s) was made in 2013 with the infrared F160W (H-band) filter (GO 13305). Since the original <em>HST</em> WFC3 image (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), further observations of this field have been made in 2015 and 2016 under <em>HST</em> snapshot programs GO-13671 and GO-14098 (part of the program of Repp\u00a0&amp; Ebeling <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). These <em>HST</em> snapshot programs included ACS/WFC observations through filters F606W and F814W, and further WFC3 observations using filters F110W and F160W. The ACS/WFC exposures were of duration 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01200\u00a0s in each filter and the additional WFC3 exposures in 2016 were 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0706\u00a0s (F110W) and 4\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01412\u00a0s (F140W). The magnitudes of the nuclear bulge components (in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> etc.) in <em>HST</em> filters are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The snapshot observations were targeted on the X-ray cluster \u2018eMACS J2229.9-0808A\u2019 (see <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://hla.stsci.edu\" target=\"_blank\">https://hla.stsci.edu</a>), corresponding to the marginally detected x-ray source 1RXS J222956.9-080823 in the first version of the RASSFSC.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The main nuclear bulge images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are resolved in the Pan-STARRS PS1 images in the Hubble Legacy Archive, and the combined Pan-STARRS z-r-g image is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. \u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019 is clearly bluer than the cluster galaxies, i.e. the source has ongoing star formation, consistent with a spiral star-forming galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"269103452\" scrollto-destination=\"269103452\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=CnTjc-M5vb-vfZytaWdUrEfVWJCwu36a3Q-6lnCCoSGo63SXnW2FLmBjDkWWD4e~x~WUNI0XjR2H0WmmOU-SeOz7eSa-JdIj1sxVomRSTiN33aGQ6h3Y62fywtcvhJxfWS29Y8hdRK99vJakL5mevfXMAFS0ySVcKD1rui3-RNY5NMQb2f-UzYd9duaRKjqIBwsgRsH-RBnXxAZ3vkc8P7Zh~TqK3JqGzf69MuyxHVHWAQNpMOSyuGvuSEc8d5ZVIYXt~bMc-7yFrqJafSPCeZCmZlpfoXiyiQlAPxDkgqtHVZH~Vw4bXfDyjPQqFhKQE1KB81vz9K82dNkXj0pnaw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS PS1 combined z-r-g image of the galaxy cluster RM J223013.1-080853.1 (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. 2016; http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/) showing the location of the lensed images. RM marks the galaxy found as the cluster \u2018centre\u2019 or brightest cluster galaxy by the rm software. The QSO or AGN is also marked, as are the lensed images A\u00a0&amp; B, which are blue and marginally resolved. The approximate location of the local gravitational centre, as determined by lensing analysis (Section\u00a05) is marked LGC.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103452/stab1375fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103452\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=Am2HRM5fEVMDP-j-9-iGIq7cGvyds7Hj6lC74lzjahSBlnmRAu6xwantu0YnuR39-dkXzsX6IBTLxxjlLQZb33Hf0ta-WYbT4do-HS6fFjGUFxMsCLbsNhGYC-Ttw4gvqf1OzQbPqN3Q680eu6naJQtctxDiE~7ERO0RCrs~pxboSy~O9FvcWWmv0sdJbLBD5aIf-4~xk7wa-2copdjYhH8fZreDULusTTJu4dWfqQOvSLq5V-3AyhscVRhVHw6t3aXaTUOk~Elb-X0Z5KkjhZDl5DwIMRdTUxTCb19hsRYaNKZo~Oj9tFNIKTWU3ZNffFSvhzSPkuw9KgTsSzj0Gg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103452&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pan-STARRS PS1 combined z-r-g image of the galaxy cluster RM J223013.1-080853.1 (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/\" target=\"_blank\">http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/</a>) showing the location of the lensed images. RM marks the galaxy found as the cluster \u2018centre\u2019 or brightest cluster galaxy by the <span class=\"small-caps\">rm</span> software. The QSO or AGN is also marked, as are the lensed images <em>A</em>\u00a0&amp; <em>B</em>, which are blue and marginally resolved. The approximate location of the local gravitational centre, as determined by lensing analysis (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>) is marked LGC.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=CnTjc-M5vb-vfZytaWdUrEfVWJCwu36a3Q-6lnCCoSGo63SXnW2FLmBjDkWWD4e~x~WUNI0XjR2H0WmmOU-SeOz7eSa-JdIj1sxVomRSTiN33aGQ6h3Y62fywtcvhJxfWS29Y8hdRK99vJakL5mevfXMAFS0ySVcKD1rui3-RNY5NMQb2f-UzYd9duaRKjqIBwsgRsH-RBnXxAZ3vkc8P7Zh~TqK3JqGzf69MuyxHVHWAQNpMOSyuGvuSEc8d5ZVIYXt~bMc-7yFrqJafSPCeZCmZlpfoXiyiQlAPxDkgqtHVZH~Vw4bXfDyjPQqFhKQE1KB81vz9K82dNkXj0pnaw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS PS1 combined z-r-g image of the galaxy cluster RM J223013.1-080853.1 (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. 2016; http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/) showing the location of the lensed images. RM marks the galaxy found as the cluster \u2018centre\u2019 or brightest cluster galaxy by the rm software. The QSO or AGN is also marked, as are the lensed images A\u00a0&amp; B, which are blue and marginally resolved. The approximate location of the local gravitational centre, as determined by lensing analysis (Section\u00a05) is marked LGC.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103452/stab1375fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103452\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=Am2HRM5fEVMDP-j-9-iGIq7cGvyds7Hj6lC74lzjahSBlnmRAu6xwantu0YnuR39-dkXzsX6IBTLxxjlLQZb33Hf0ta-WYbT4do-HS6fFjGUFxMsCLbsNhGYC-Ttw4gvqf1OzQbPqN3Q680eu6naJQtctxDiE~7ERO0RCrs~pxboSy~O9FvcWWmv0sdJbLBD5aIf-4~xk7wa-2copdjYhH8fZreDULusTTJu4dWfqQOvSLq5V-3AyhscVRhVHw6t3aXaTUOk~Elb-X0Z5KkjhZDl5DwIMRdTUxTCb19hsRYaNKZo~Oj9tFNIKTWU3ZNffFSvhzSPkuw9KgTsSzj0Gg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103452&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pan-STARRS PS1 combined z-r-g image of the galaxy cluster RM J223013.1-080853.1 (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/\" target=\"_blank\">http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/</a>) showing the location of the lensed images. RM marks the galaxy found as the cluster \u2018centre\u2019 or brightest cluster galaxy by the <span class=\"small-caps\">rm</span> software. The QSO or AGN is also marked, as are the lensed images <em>A</em>\u00a0&amp; <em>B</em>, which are blue and marginally resolved. The approximate location of the local gravitational centre, as determined by lensing analysis (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>) is marked LGC.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Surrounding the lensed images is a galaxy cluster for which the apparent members have SDSS photometric redshifts averaging 0.526\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.018, as measured and catalogued in redMaPPerClusters in the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database, NED: RM J223013.1-080853.1. The redMaPPer catalogue cluster members are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (using the Tool for OPerations on Catalogues And Tables, TOPCAT (Taylor <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>)). There is no core- or central-Dominant (cD) galaxy present, unlike the situation in many richer and more relaxed clusters. The catalogued RM cluster centre is positioned on one of the brightest galaxies, labelled <em>RM</em> in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, but this galaxy is probably not the actual cluster centre, as seen from its peripheral position, and also suggested by our multiple image lensing analysis (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>). This problem of identification of the cluster centre is in common with many RM clusters (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The total number of \u2243 <em>L</em>* galaxies is about 60; so, by comparison with other clusters (Andreon\u00a0&amp; Hurn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), we might expect the total cluster mass to be weakly constrained to 3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>.</p>                        <a id=\"269103458\" scrollto-destination=\"269103458\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=aQrzvd7Gu~rM5pHK9DRHkEG6w6Bu2E3QLXxJW~XlIafwqYsh1lP~aQtwEmD7m3ru5ji8QrhyudcYav17z56nTm1BjkHsLjNe-dsgP1dgs0MeAK-HU1Z~5b9VWB-dzgEyvMHLzKbBlX2uDNSjsGdIAn8usxelNLXXXpq7nAdgMZOa3UbLEUMt3UKRSivRkOFku74EHg2W3siIYzSS1FrH74v5Oet2eBsjLmh5OiOyCkEt8dm2obAuSJqG8SitnyEHmtYxwFxmQQqclUUk85MhA84fwFXL0YyxGX1qBk1XAf1mtZfnmNH4MJUeckjXo-z-QYM5X5PYBn5ITxBmuN4tDQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"redMaPPer cluster RM223013.1-080853.1 showing locations of photometric cluster members. The galaxy labelled RM is the one found by redMaPPer as the brightest. The position of lensed fold images A and B (Fig.\u00a01) is marked as L.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103458/stab1375fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103458\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=ZoP0LV5dDRjqF45ZApXDBijFms1ym58yXN6ophGSnDRTncF~-YdBfbkJ7KcoU21HfxRFHCwfwczei4tk4HCSOaAgZz8AoRD7LGiIr4jSZGIEuV10OcGJDvw3~klWwV2-ukzxy-XTiyXpMQA3vJXimPaVgXCyasqSP1IwovF3470jyKxMhc-1EaQZ4524STh-IJzrDSBbKkQ1InCW-G7eRXjG1vhGArYwfkdHUBoyvRs9Q-u4Wek34MopEmn8jaw6skxlNq3ccPVbzSb0EdtQ9aZMMyf-CiPvAQ9GTZ78dLLvI495ZHX05nYK3Ijy50ew2ChiAZk4Qpa2vGAHZpk8Qw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103458&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">redMaPPer cluster RM223013.1-080853.1 showing locations of photometric cluster members. The galaxy labelled RM is the one found by redMaPPer as the brightest. The position of lensed fold images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) is marked as L.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">A very faint gravitational arc appears in the <em>HST</em> F606 images, centred at RA 22<sup>h</sup>30<sup>m</sup>08<sup>s</sup>.97, Dec. \u221208\u00b009\u203242\u2033.0, and even more faintly in F814W (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). The arc is apparently split into three parts and possibly indicates that the centre of mass of the cluster is likely somewhere between <em>A</em>/<em>B</em> and counterimage <em>C</em>, but the faint arc may be additionally lensed by a background galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"269103463\" scrollto-destination=\"269103463\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section
