class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tbl3fn1\"></span><div content-id=\"tbl3fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. (a) as in MCG 8-11-11 (Ulrich et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>)</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/269103599\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"utbl1\" data-id=\"utbl1\"> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th colspan=\"11\">Objects<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Ion\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> (doublet)\u00a0</td><td>Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> (doublet)\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>\u00a0</td><td>Ti <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, note (a)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Rest \u03bb \u00c5.\u00a0</td><td>2676\u00a0</td><td>2712\u00a0</td><td>2753\u00a0</td><td>2766\u00a0</td><td>2796\u00a0</td><td>2803\u00a0</td><td>2905\u00a0</td><td>3004\u00a0</td><td>3007\u00a0</td><td>3074\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Observed \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>4870\u00a0</td><td>4935\u00a0</td><td>5010\u00a0</td><td>5035\u00a0</td><td>5089\u00a0</td><td>5101\u00a0</td><td>5287\u00a0</td><td>5465\u00a0</td><td>5473\u00a0</td><td>5600\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th colspan=\"11\">Objects<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Ion\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> (doublet)\u00a0</td><td>Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> (doublet)\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>\u00a0</td><td>Ti <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, note (a)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Rest \u03bb \u00c5.\u00a0</td><td>2676\u00a0</td><td>2712\u00a0</td><td>2753\u00a0</td><td>2766\u00a0</td><td>2796\u00a0</td><td>2803\u00a0</td><td>2905\u00a0</td><td>3004\u00a0</td><td>3007\u00a0</td><td>3074\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Observed \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>4870\u00a0</td><td>4935\u00a0</td><td>5010\u00a0</td><td>5035\u00a0</td><td>5089\u00a0</td><td>5101\u00a0</td><td>5287\u00a0</td><td>5465\u00a0</td><td>5473\u00a0</td><td>5600\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tbl3fn1\"></span><div content-id=\"tbl3fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. (a) as in MCG 8-11-11 (Ulrich et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>)</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/269103599\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The KCWI spectra show that all three nuclear bulge images <em>A</em>1, <em>B</em>1, and <em>C</em>1 have a redshift of 0.8200\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0005, confirming the Gemini GMOS-N spectrum above. The spectrum of counterimage object <em>C</em>7, lensed as images <em>A</em>7 and <em>B</em>7 also displays the same absorption lines at a redshift of 0.8200. Given the appearance of <em>C</em>7 on the edge of counterimage <em>C</em> (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>), we conclude that this is a superstarburst region or a starburst clump in an outer arm of the galaxy, similar to an object in Abell S1063 at redshift 0.6 (Walth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) or the starburst clump in NGC 2207 (Kaufman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Such \u00a0kpc-sized starburst H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> clumps are high redshift counterparts to actively star-forming clumps in nearby massive turbulent disc galaxies (Fisher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Elmegreen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103612 id=\"269103612\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 ANALYSIS OF THE IMAGE CONFIGURATION AND MORPHOLOGY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To further investigate the global cluster shape, we consider mass-density profiles which may be capable of generating three images of the same background source showing a high degree of alignment like our observed triple-image-configuration. An axisymmetric NFW mass-density profile is one possible choice. This is capable of generating three images of the same background source in the observed configuration, when the source is located inside the caustic curve and asymptotically approaching it. Focusing on the morphology of the generated multiple images, attention is not paid here to the creation of the exact lens and source positions along the line of sight when simulating an NFW profile. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> (left) shows its caustic. Using image\u00a0<em>C</em> of the observed multiple image configuration to play the role of the background source at the position shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> (left), this NFW-profile gravitational lens generates the triple-image configuration as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> (right).</p>                        <a id=\"269103616\" scrollto-destination=\"269103616\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=XS3GFNv279s5KX3XWJy2umLa7IDT2kV1JTpFzzbTnZjoCS2uphYXVTaV749CesuxJo1HFyzgbxf27cFpy2gi7bD5e36tvb33qgwI9J8epEThL7LBNZflH3RS3v6LARyvWRMMRsdPbf7fJlrQBHwXSbP5qBmm~MXuAwRq9ktf59J95bMWaiPWp7LqHspYsUZReSiAA-fH8fuqb-UyNDBjlnLFZs6Qc~U1rKMMPNXnxBvnzEpHWa7biZJrejr6QtU1SByJ5KwrvX6wd~6DgnuZVbwNp0hHQhvwsQllxudLKRPmHM8voiRDY0uCaVvUScBgA1mnTVT-wPK95k9iabAjWA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Simulation of the multiple-image generation using an NFW profile: mimicking the source with the observed image\u00a0C and placing it close to the caustic (blue circle) of an NFW profile (left), this NFW profile gravitational lens generates a triple-image configuration consisting of a counterimage\u00a0C outside the tangential critical curve (red arc) and a fold configuration with images\u00a0A and B straddling the radial critical curve (red circle; right). But the parities of the observed images do not match the simulation (see text) \u2013 the NFW model is too simple and does not match the observations.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103616/stab1375fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103616\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=saPcB1faWp3qxx7meNvTPyqiN~myVXOhPLZ0Vyqt~LYfvNt0etE6wj-F6kN3MV60k8bEbAMTbPRhJXBynbNIDHHUEzt6frwqf5v4lxwnTW2cngWnTAwU753oQDaMRAHqI8dOKmQVFuLNGK9aIIkBOqbIuzWGzeiOBNBENhH2WLk1Gv5Td6QgmvBmqC4v4UZJok0iQ2BeRBuV6lxIfiUkkryvH~YV6dvAI9Lknk3DCF5z-YQV91npy-wK4SwoF4ortiIKUW5a2DqgMqJgqs3ICrggG45mtnKxj3Y4ND367l9ApS7GqMy-bP58CiLx37jR~s28AGSkVuQsLFg2qsomcg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103616&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Simulation of the multiple-image generation using an NFW profile: mimicking the source with the observed image\u00a0<em>C</em> and placing it close to the caustic (blue circle) of an NFW profile (left), this NFW profile gravitational lens generates a triple-image configuration consisting of a counterimage\u00a0<em>C</em> outside the tangential critical curve (red arc) and a fold configuration with images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> straddling the radial critical curve (red circle; right). But the parities of the observed images do not match the simulation (see text) \u2013 the NFW model is too simple and does not match the observations.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=XS3GFNv279s5KX3XWJy2umLa7IDT2kV1JTpFzzbTnZjoCS2uphYXVTaV749CesuxJo1HFyzgbxf27cFpy2gi7bD5e36tvb33qgwI9J8epEThL7LBNZflH3RS3v6LARyvWRMMRsdPbf7fJlrQBHwXSbP5qBmm~MXuAwRq9ktf59J95bMWaiPWp7LqHspYsUZReSiAA-fH8fuqb-UyNDBjlnLFZs6Qc~U1rKMMPNXnxBvnzEpHWa7biZJrejr6QtU1SByJ5KwrvX6wd~6DgnuZVbwNp0hHQhvwsQllxudLKRPmHM8voiRDY0uCaVvUScBgA1mnTVT-wPK95k9iabAjWA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Simulation of the multiple-image generation using an NFW profile: mimicking the source with the observed image\u00a0C and placing it close to the caustic (blue circle) of an NFW profile (left), this NFW profile gravitational lens generates a triple-image configuration consisting of a counterimage\u00a0C outside the tangential critical curve (red arc) and a fold configuration with images\u00a0A and B straddling the radial critical curve (red circle; right). But the parities of the observed images do not match the simulation (see text) \u2013 the NFW model is too simple and does not match the observations.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103616/stab1375fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103616\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=saPcB1faWp3qxx7meNvTPyqiN~myVXOhPLZ0Vyqt~LYfvNt0etE6wj-F6kN3MV60k8bEbAMTbPRhJXBynbNIDHHUEzt6frwqf5v4lxwnTW2cngWnTAwU753oQDaMRAHqI8dOKmQVFuLNGK9aIIkBOqbIuzWGzeiOBNBENhH2WLk1Gv5Td6QgmvBmqC4v4UZJok0iQ2BeRBuV6lxIfiUkkryvH~YV6dvAI9Lknk3DCF5z-YQV91npy-wK4SwoF4ortiIKUW5a2DqgMqJgqs3ICrggG45mtnKxj3Y4ND367l9ApS7GqMy-bP58CiLx37jR~s28AGSkVuQsLFg2qsomcg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103616&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Simulation of the multiple-image generation using an NFW profile: mimicking the source with the observed image\u00a0<em>C</em> and placing it close to the caustic (blue circle) of an NFW profile (left), this NFW profile gravitational lens generates a triple-image configuration consisting of a counterimage\u00a0<em>C</em> outside the tangential critical curve (red arc) and a fold configuration with images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> straddling the radial critical curve (red circle; right). But the parities of the observed images do not match the simulation (see text) \u2013 the NFW model is too simple and does not match the observations.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We clearly see that the radial-arc configuration of the two simulated merging fold images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> does not resemble the morphology of the observed fold images. The parities do not match, i.e.\u00a0the simulated image\u00a0<em>A</em> has the same parity as the simulated image\u00a0<em>C</em>, while images\u00a0<em>B</em> and <em>C</em> have the same parities in the observed configuration. This becomes more obvious in the coloured versions in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>, and is even clearer when we compare the observed positions of the bright feature on the SE extremity of image\u00a0<em>C</em>, and the corresponding feature in observed images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, with the positions of this feature in simulated images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. Furthermore, an NFW-profile causes a perfect vertical alignment of the three multiple images while image\u00a0<em>C</em> in the observations in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> has a small offset from the line through images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. Thus, it is unlikely that Hamilton\u2019s Object is a radial-arc configuration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Next, we replace the NFW profile by a realistically simulated generic cluster lens called <em>Hera</em>. The deflecting mass-density profile is a high-resolution zoom-in simulation of an <em>N</em>-body cosmological simulation, as detailed in Meneghetti et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). It is located at redshift <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0= 0.507, which is close to the lens redshift <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0= 0.53 of the galaxy cluster lens discussed here. We place image\u00a0<em>C</em> as a model for the background source close to the caustic belonging to a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0= 0.82, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> (left). As a lensing result, we obtain a triple-image configuration shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> (right), which clearly resembles the observed configuration. The parities match and the difference in the relative orientations of the fold images with respect to the critical curve can be explained by the relative orientation of the source and the caustic curve. In order to obtain the observed small horizontal offset between images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> with respect to image\u00a0<em>C</em>, the source must lie closer to the caustic line than to the caustic cusp point at the left-most position of the caustic in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>. As detailed in Schneider, Ehlers\u00a0&amp; Falco (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>), (chapter 6), multiple images caused by lensed sources close to the cusp point align almost perfectly on top of each other and often merge into giant arcs, which is not the case here.</p>                        <a id=\"269103628\" scrollto-destination=\"269103628\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=StG5cC7E9AryR2DUbJlAUOwUWm4xT1fRQ4qKQw4L-YmMdz-XePcC9f81r20odCAuqLeu6yxsmFoFUkZVv1AGqpNL6epj10-s6e1UbSkL-dqjCNrjMCRt9f5eaaRCSXGxIUSoWubwXESQZ8hQbnESLEN9ZpAAmSVRxjHJFZ5XIsTSpFrrA~3zBcK8TJKVeJm3OdRodIj0SezWZj5~glsPkTeMKNH~UxGqVu3gcrzZc-aS1gU72bSpjH6qhTF5g3uoTFrXKxnh6FNkx4O-20h8JqimyPk-YnW4Fz~Qw2~ZhE7tNQKf400koMs25XMnSuzlhIx2TNS01vu7Ck3BWf1OKg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Simulation of the multiple-image generation using the Hera DM profile: same as Fig.\u00a010 but for the mass-density profile Hera detailed in Meneghetti et\u00a0al. 2017. The parities of the simulated images match the observations.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103628/stab1375fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103628\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&Signature=QBrciVTjREusq~eL~i3YFwVHMINrMS1S63TZrb0Tmw~usWEXydFzQ1f6pKPI6GXvR8x5vxC9nTnuL9M5COoxZJCryDYif5ATNuvbVi485yGGpw1Jl~dVRQcgZ17NBsokMxn~Bdot5oqdab7FqPykk3KvEFBQHG~uDLFqRfORgr8ISMt~~fzXQSAj6q~XebV5fM3GhjsQ8e8dq9lq6tpRxBdJYusJ8RNr0EGrKT1rXtjNXXi1Gs5DrorcTehlnN7VRkP1ldcK0hy3dgBkATMJsEG3sU2e782wfy5~KJfAMtS-BdPSvxdVA2C1qW9ZxBU9qfAZL5PeWDAOiCMIbWcPIg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103628&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Simulation of the multiple-image generation using the <em>Hera</em> DM profile: same as Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> but for the mass-density profile <em>Hera</em> detailed in Meneghetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>. The parities of the simulated images match the observations.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=StG5cC7E9AryR2DUbJlAUOwUWm4xT1fRQ4qKQw4L-YmMdz-XePcC9f81r20odCAuqLeu6yxsmFoFUkZVv1AGqpNL6epj10-s6e1UbSkL-dqjCNrjMCRt9f5eaaRCSXGxIUSoWubwXESQZ8hQbnESLEN9ZpAAmSVRxjHJFZ5XIsTSpFrrA~3zBcK8TJKVeJm3OdRodIj0SezWZj5~glsPkTeMKNH~UxGqVu3gcrzZc-aS1gU72bSpjH6qhTF5g3uoTFrXKxnh6FNkx4O-20h8JqimyPk-YnW4Fz~Qw2~ZhE7tNQKf400koMs25XMnSuzlhIx2TNS01vu7Ck3BWf1OKg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Simulation of the multiple-image generation using the Hera DM profile: same as Fig.\u00a010 but for the mass-density profile Hera detailed in Meneghetti et\u00a0al. 2017. The parities of the simulated images match the observations.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103628/stab1375fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103628\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&Signature=QBrciVTjREusq~eL~i3YFwVHMINrMS1S63TZrb0Tmw~usWEXydFzQ1f6pKPI6GXvR8x5vxC9nTnuL9M5COoxZJCryDYif5ATNuvbVi485yGGpw1Jl~dVRQcgZ17NBsokMxn~Bdot5oqdab7FqPykk3KvEFBQHG~uDLFqRfORgr8ISMt~~fzXQSAj6q~XebV5fM3GhjsQ8e8dq9lq6tpRxBdJYusJ8RNr0EGrKT1rXtjNXXi1Gs5DrorcTehlnN7VRkP1ldcK0hy3dgBkATMJsEG3sU2e782wfy5~KJfAMtS-BdPSvxdVA2C1qW9ZxBU9qfAZL5PeWDAOiCMIbWcPIg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103628&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Simulation of the multiple-image generation using the <em>Hera</em> DM profile: same as Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> but for the mass-density profile <em>Hera</em> detailed in Meneghetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>. The parities of the simulated images match the observations.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103637 id=\"269103637\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 GRAVITATIONAL LENS RECONSTRUCTION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103641 id=\"269103641\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Applicable lens reconstructions</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Lens reconstructions aiming at constraining the mass-density map in the entire lensing region usually require a high density of multiple lensed images in the cluster region or complementary information about the gravitational lens, such as the positions, surface brightness, or velocity dispersion information of the cluster member galaxies, or x-ray emission maps. The more data that are available, the more accurate and precise the reconstruction of the mass-density profile: see e.g. Johnson\u00a0&amp; Sharon (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), Lotz et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For Hamilton\u2019s Object, as detailed in Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>, although we have detailed information on this one triple configuration, the available information on the surrounding galaxy cluster is still very sparse and limited to SDSS photometry. A gravitational lens reconstruction over the entire lensing region is thus not yet possible due to the lack of further (spectroscopically confirmed) multiple lensed systems. We therefore use the observation-based approach detailed in Wagner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) for a <em>local</em> lens reconstruction in the vicinity of the three confirmed multiple images. The goal is the determination of local lens properties at the positions of the multiple images directly from the observable features. In this way, we obtain lens properties that do not require any specific assumptions about the global morphology of the mass-density profile in the lensing region. The formalism is based on Chapter\u00a06 of Schneider et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>) and exploits the fact that local lens properties can be retrieved from a Taylor expansion around multiple image locations or around points on the critical curve, respectively. Consequently, these local lens properties can be derived for any gravitational lens and do not require specific assumptions about the global mass-density profile. Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.2</a> details the necessary ingredients and prerequisites to perform the local lens reconstruction. Subsequently, Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.4</a> give an overview of reconstructed local lens properties and their interpretation, respectively. Lastly, we use the local lens properties in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.5</a> to reconstruct the surface brightness profile of the spiral galaxy which is the common background source of all three observed images.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103647 id=\"269103647\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Local lens properties from three resolved multiple images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Hamilton\u2019s Object consists of three multiple images showing resolved features that can be identified in the intensity profiles of the images. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> shows the seven identifiable features, after assembling a coloured version of the <em>HST</em> observation consisting of F606W, F814W, and the F110W filter bands (longer wavelengths are not used here because of poorer resolution). These features have been located to a precision of one pixel, corresponding to 0.09\u2033 on the sky at the given pixel resolution of the F110W filter band, which has the lowest resolution of the three filter bands used.</p>                        <a id=\"269103653\" scrollto-destination=\"269103653\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=bEtZYJkbekyGHmdkXak784T4XoPo4RWByXT2CZkf1oq8WQoXhmT7JYXZjjBkvv8vLGEW2Lj6FeuAuqezzhHSCRz0a43PpCdMNXHabV1AIxiha~PSVNzHC7qNnWABj64ddzFoV9hpP69gLwDCeyCX6IpZtKqV1Jr3xiO0FnIjNxdmaqYnZucNWVjR4PM-ycruMNym5X~4iPqxSsXOHeIfHt2tuz3nMKbAoo4U4~qMUU0jtat-qzhStZAwGDkDcc76G1yHw3TTfINxDANp6xRtAoSEZMaNd-eDmlz4~YY7J-db1B5ERxavWokZ32~6Ln-JZRK0wlsuls4bJsTDwGlCow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Identification of individual surface brightness features in all multiple images in the multiband HST observations: the two fold images\u00a0A and B show seven corresponding features (the positions are marked by the yellow circles annotated by 1\u20137 in each image) which can also be found in the counter-image\u00a0C. The figure is stretched E-W relative to N-S by a factor 2.2 in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103653/stab1375fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103653\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&Signature=u8ivWHPFzVL-FQkUi-H11Xm-tc2Zi~bDalOrWdLO1FqdjkSWJ2Yf0XP1jHXIhew60l2Ofsd0y9XUzLqEvQNIiGX5u8WegGxK6EtScoODAxpPoILryR48uaSvpv5PUwYR2IpO6paTgl3rTZE70tm2uoXOjKp05ayTibLBPLGcp0guNx5fx7aWUilDG5Bu~7-ndYuHgLjxngLci7zGN-YW~LCfqLpRcSvgIfqj~Q-L0JdV-2X0-ZyIUcyajqInLSeaUkrvZVTQzyVZYQ0WaQzx6AOzulz7d6Cc4rGHt6INOfOWI5fru0I-EWDXr6Q0Yxjo9ryBBl-ODse8-7n~emHtXA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103653&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Identification of individual surface brightness features in all multiple images in the multiband <em>HST</em> observations: the two fold images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> show seven corresponding features (the positions are marked by the yellow circles annotated by 1\u20137 in each image) which can also be found in the counter-image\u00a0<em>C</em>. The figure is stretched E-W relative to N-S by a factor 2.2 in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=bEtZYJkbekyGHmdkXak784T4XoPo4RWByXT2CZkf1oq8WQoXhmT7JYXZjjBkvv8vLGEW2Lj6FeuAuqezzhHSCRz0a43PpCdMNXHabV1AIxiha~PSVNzHC7qNnWABj64ddzFoV9hpP69gLwDCeyCX6IpZtKqV1Jr3xiO0FnIjNxdmaqYnZucNWVjR4PM-ycruMNym5X~4iPqxSsXOHeIfHt2tuz3nMKbAoo4U4~qMUU0jtat-qzhStZAwGDkDcc76G1yHw3TTfINxDANp6xRtAoSEZMaNd-eDmlz4~YY7J-db1B5ERxavWokZ32~6Ln-JZRK0wlsuls4bJsTDwGlCow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Identification of individual surface brightness features in all multiple images in the multiband HST observations: the two fold images\u00a0A and B show seven corresponding features (the positions are marked by the yellow circles annotated by 1\u20137 in each image) which can also be found in the counter-image\u00a0C. The figure is stretched E-W relative to N-S by a factor 2.2 in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103653/stab1375fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103653\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&Signature=u8ivWHPFzVL-FQkUi-H11Xm-tc2Zi~bDalOrWdLO1FqdjkSWJ2Yf0XP1jHXIhew60l2Ofsd0y9XUzLqEvQNIiGX5u8WegGxK6EtScoODAxpPoILryR48uaSvpv5PUwYR2IpO6paTgl3rTZE70tm2uoXOjKp05ayTibLBPLGcp0guNx5fx7aWUilDG5Bu~7-ndYuHgLjxngLci7zGN-YW~LCfqLpRcSvgIfqj~Q-L0JdV-2X0-ZyIUcyajqInLSeaUkrvZVTQzyVZYQ0WaQzx6AOzulz7d6Cc4rGHt6INOfOWI5fru0I-EWDXr6Q0Yxjo9ryBBl-ODse8-7n~emHtXA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103653&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Identification of individual surface brightness features in all multiple images in the multiband <em>HST</em> observations: the two fold images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> show seven corresponding features (the positions are marked by the yellow circles annotated by 1\u20137 in each image) which can also be found in the counter-image\u00a0<em>C</em>. The figure is stretched E-W relative to N-S by a factor 2.2 in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">This multiple image configuration with the seven features fulfils the prerequisites to be analysed by the approach summarized in Wagner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). This means that we assume that the local lens properties extending over the image areas on the sky covered by these seven features can be assumed constant to a good approximation. Because feature\u00a07 is on the edge of the galaxy (see discussion above in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.3</a>), we decided to investigate its influence on the reconstruction of the local lens properties, and so we first determine the local lens properties excluding feature\u00a07 from the analysis and subsequently repeat the procedure including it. Comparing both reconstructions should reveal whether the local lens properties can be really assumed constant over the extended area covered by all features or whether this approximation is only valid for the smaller area covered by features\u00a01\u20136.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the implementation of the software package <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> for our calculations. Details about the method can be found in Wagner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), and another example, an analysis of a five-multiple-image configuration in the galaxy cluster CL0024, can be found in Wagner, Liesenborgs\u00a0&amp; Tessore (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The resolved features in the galaxy images in CL0024 were identified in a single filter band observation, as were those in Hamilton\u2019s Object (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>), but the features in Hamilton\u2019s Object became clearer after stacking the three filter bands mentioned above into a coloured picture, and the combined image was needed in order to measure local lens properties. (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>). Due to the extensions of images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> orthogonal to the critical curve, Hamilton\u2019s Object also provides one of the first lensed galaxies with resolved surface brightness features from which we can reconstruct a local approximation to the critical curve between the images.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103666 id=\"269103666\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> results</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We first run <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> using the six features\u00a01\u20136 in each multiple image, as marked in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>, assuming uncorrelated imprecisions in <em>x</em>- and <em>y</em>-directions of 1\u00a0pixel. Afterwards, we repeat the <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> analysis using all seven features in the multiple images. As the reference image, we choose image\u00a0<em>A</em> because it covers a larger area than image\u00a0<em>C</em> and it yields tighter confidence bounds for the local lens properties than using image\u00a0<em>B</em> as reference. The resulting local lens properties are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _{\\mathrm{red}}^2 = 0.87$|</span> smaller than one, indicates that the transformation of multiple images on to each other can be successfully set up on the basis of these six features. Since it is closer to one than the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _\\mathrm{red}^2$|</span> when using image\u00a0<em>B</em> as reference image, the lens properties are less prone to overfitting. For all seven features, we obtain <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _\\mathrm{red}^2 = 1.64$|\u2060</span>. Hence, there is a slight bias and a possible hint for non-constant local lens properties over the larger area of all seven features. The local lens properties determined from the transformations are the following (for definitions of these parameters, see Wagner\u00a0&amp; Tessore (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>)):</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The relative ratios between convergences \u03ba <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nf_i \\equiv \\dfrac{1-\\kappa _A}{1-\\kappa _i} \\,\\,, \\quad i = B, C \\,\\,,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>is a measure of the mass-density ratio between the different multiple image positions because \u03ba<sub><em>i</em></sub>, <em>i</em>\u00a0= <em>A</em>,\u00a0<em>B</em>, and <em>C</em> is the mass density at the position of a multiple image scaled by the so-called critical mass density to obtain a dimensionless quantity.</div></li><li><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The reduced shear <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\boldsymbol{g}_i = (g_{i,1}, g_{i,2}) \\equiv \\dfrac{\\boldsymbol{\\gamma }_i}{1-\\kappa _i} \\,\\,, \\quad i=A, B, C \\,\\,,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>is a measure of the local distortion per mass density that the lens exerts at the position of a multiple image. From its components, the magnitude and the direction of the reduced shear can be determined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n|\\boldsymbol{g}_i| = \\sqrt{g_{i,1}^2 + g_{i,2}^2} \\,\\,, \\quad \\varphi _{g,i} = \\dfrac{1}{2} \\text{atan} \\left(\\dfrac{g_{i,2}}{g_{i,1}} \\right) \\,\\,,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>for <em>i</em>\u00a0= <em>A</em>,\u00a0<em>B</em>, and <em>C</em>. At a critical curve, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\boldsymbol{g}|=1$|\u2060</span>, with values larger than 1 inside and decreasing values smaller than 1 outside.</div></li><li><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The magnification ratio <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\mathcal {J}_i \\equiv \\dfrac{\\text{det}(M_A)}{\\text{det}(M_i)} \\,\\,, M_i = (1-\\kappa _i) \\left({\\begin{array}{*{10}c}1-g_{i,1} &amp; -g_{i,2} \\\\\r\n-g_{i,2} &amp; 1+g_{i,1} \\end{array}} \\right) \\,\\,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>between images\u00a0<em>i</em>\u00a0= <em>B</em> and <em>C</em> to image\u00a0<em>A</em> is determined from the <em>f<sub>i</sub></em> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{g}_i$|\u2060</span>. It serves as a cross-check quantity, if flux ratios between the multiple images are measured. For images in a fold configuration, we expect a magnification ratio close to \u22121. This is physically interpreted as having equal magnifications for both images but a reversed parity. Thus, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {J}$|</span> shows the relative parity between the multiple images. If local lens properties with relative parities are retrieved that are inconsistent with the observed relative parities, the respective <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> result can be refuted and it can be doubted whether the chosen multiple image candidates actually belong to the same background source.</div></li></ul>                        <a id=\"269103673\" scrollto-destination=\"269103673\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Synopsis of local lens properties obtained from Hamilton\u2019s Object using features\u00a01\u20136 (left) and using all seven features marked in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> (right): name of the local lens property (first column), its most-likely value, ML (second column), its mean value, Mean (third column), and the width of the sampled distribution between the 16th and the 84th percentile, Std (fourth column), based on 10\u2009000 samples around the positions of the features marked in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. Details concerning the treatment of the statistics can be found in Wagner\u00a0&amp; Tessore (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and Wagner, Liesenborgs\u00a0&amp; Tessore (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens prop.<span .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>g</em><sub><em>A</em>, 1</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.78\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.02\u00a0</td><td>0.73\u00a0</td><td><em>g</em><sub><em>A</em>, 1</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.97\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.10\u00a0</td><td>0.53\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em><sub><em>A</em>, 2</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.19\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.20\u00a0</td><td>0.08\u00a0</td><td><em>g</em><sub><em>A</em>, 2</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.03\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.04\u00a0</td><td>0.06\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {J}_B$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.27\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.27\u00a0</td><td>0.10\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {J}_B$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.37\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.36\u00a0</td><td>0.08\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>f<sub>B</sub></em>\u00a0</td><td>0.59\u00a0</td><td>0.60\u00a0</td><td>0.24\u00a0</td><td><em>f<sub>B</sub></em>\u00a0</td><td>0.58\u00a0</td><td>0.57\u00a0</td><td>0.15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em><sub><em>B</em>, 1</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.56\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.56\u00a0</td><td>0.21\u00a0</td><td><em>g</em><sub><em>B</em>, 1</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.53\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.53\u00a0</td><td>0.14\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em><sub><em>B</em>, 2</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.25\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.25\u00a0</td><td>0.05\u00a0</td><td><em>g</em><sub><em>B</em>, 2</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.14\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.14\u00a0</td><td>0.04\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {J}_C$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.58\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.58\u00a0</td><td>0.10\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {J}_C$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.53\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.53\u00a0</td><td>0.07\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>f<sub>C</sub></em>\u00a0</td><td>0.51\u00a0</td><td>0.59\u00a0</td><td>2.03\u00a0</td><td><em>f<sub>C</sub></em>\u00a0</td><td>0.42\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td><td>0.42\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em><sub><em>C</em>, 1</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.03\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.11\u00a0</td><td>2.14\u00a0</td><td><em>g</em><sub><em>C</em>, 1</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.09\u00a0</td><td>0.07\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em><sub><em>C</em>, 2</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.02\u00a0</td><td>0.43\u00a0</td><td><em>g</em><sub><em>C</em>, 2</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0</td><td>0.12\u00a0</td><td>0.06\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/269103673\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparing the most-likely value and the mean value for each local lens property in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left) and (right) individually, we find that each of the ML and mean values agree with each other within the 68\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence level. There are three confidence bounds that exceed the mean and most-likely lens property value by about an order of magnitude for image\u00a0<em>C</em> in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left), while only one local lens property in image\u00a0<em>C</em> shows such behaviour in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (right). However, for most of these local lens properties, the components of the reduced shear are close to zero and confidence bounds larger than the value can occur and also did occur in the example of CL0024. In addition, we observe a reduced size of the confidence bounds when increasing the image area, as Std in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left) is always larger than Std in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (right). Beyond the relatively good quality of confidence bounds, there is a high degree of coincidence between the most-likely and mean local lens property value, corroborating the successful pairwise transformation of the multiple images on to each other and thus, yielding further evidence that these three images originate from the same background source. Comparing the most-likely local lens properties of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left) and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (right) with each other, we find coincidences within the confidence bounds for all local lens properties but <em>g</em><sub><em>A</em>, 2</sub> and <em>g</em><sub><em>B</em>, 2</sub>. This high degree of coincidence between the two <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> reconstructions implies that the bias when using all seven features is really very small.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103676 id=\"269103676\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-4>5.4 <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> evaluation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparing the relative positions of the six (or seven) features between the multiple images, we find that images\u00a0<em>B</em> and <em>C</em> have the same parity and image\u00a0<em>A</em> has reversed parity. These relative parities are typical for tangential cusp configurations of three multiple images and are also found for the analogous configuration in CL0024. Hence, <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> yields the correct relative parities with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\text{sign}(\\mathcal {J}_B) = \\text{sign}(\\mathcal {J}_C) = - \\text{sign}(\\mathcal {J}_A)$|\u2060</span>. In addition, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {J}_B$|</span> is close to \u22121, as expected for the fold configuration consisting of images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {J}_B$|</span> is smaller than \u22121, indicating that image\u00a0<em>B</em> is more strongly magnified than image\u00a0<em>A</em>. Comparing the predicted magnification ratios of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left) and (right) to the observed flux ratios for all available wavelengths in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, we find an overall good degree of agreement. As Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> only contains the flux ratios of the central flux from core feature\u00a01, we can conclude that the eastern and western additional parts of the galaxy only add minor contributions to the surface brightness distribution, which seems realistic from visual inspection of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> and confirms the consistency of our analysis with the observations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Next, we evaluate the <em>f<sub>i</sub></em>, which follows the same trend in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left) and (right). According to equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">1</a>), the positivity of both <em>f<sub>i</sub></em> implies that all convergences are either smaller or larger than one. Since the multiple images are supposed to form a tangential cusp configuration at an outer critical curve, it is more likely that all convergences are smaller than one. In that case, 1 &gt; <em>f<sub>B</sub></em> &gt; <em>f<sub>C</sub></em> implies that \u03ba<sub><em>A</em></sub> &gt; \u03ba<sub><em>B</em></sub> &gt; \u03ba<sub><em>C</em></sub>. So we can conclude that the mass density at the image positions is decreasing outwards, if image\u00a0<em>A</em> is closer to the cluster centre than image\u00a0<em>B</em>, which, in turn, is closer to the cluster centre than image\u00a0<em>C</em>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The interpretations of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {J}_i$|</span> and <em>f<sub>i</sub></em> are consistent with the reduced shears. Using equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ3\"></span><a href=\"#equ3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>) to convert the reduced shear components to their polar representation, we find that <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\boldsymbol{g}_A| = 1.79 \\gt |\\boldsymbol{g}_B| = 0.62$|</span> for Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left) and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\boldsymbol{g}_A| = 1.97 \\gt |\\boldsymbol{g}_B| = 0.55$|</span> for Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (right). This implies that image\u00a0<em>A</em> is closer to the cluster centre and farther from the critical curve which occurs at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\boldsymbol{g}|=1$|\u2060</span>. Consequently, we expect image\u00a0<em>B</em> to be more strongly magnified due to its position closer to the critical curve.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Wagner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and Wagner\u00a0&amp; Tessore (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), the peak position of a parabolic approximation to the critical curve was derived based on the positions and shapes of the three cusp images. While the multiple images of Hamilton\u2019s Object are too far from the peak position to allow for a parabolic approximation to the critical curve, we roughly estimate the peak position by plotting the most-likely directions of the reduced shears for all images, starting at the central position of each image. The latter is determined by <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> as the so-called anchor point of each image. (For image\u00a0<em>A</em>, it is fixed to the centroid of all feature positions.) The crossings of the three reduced shear directions of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left), as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a> give a first impression of the extent of the critical curve for the redshift of the source. In this analysis, we first note the bias of the reconstruction in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (right) because the direction derived for image\u00a0<em>A</em> crosses the one from Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left) due to the different sign of <em>g</em><sub><em>A</em>, 2</sub>. Yet, within the confidence bounds, negative <em>g</em><sub><em>A</em>, 2</sub> and shear directions pointing to the most-likely cusp position of the critical curve can still occur.</p>                        <a id=\"269103684\" scrollto-destination=\"269103684\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=pr-au7o4ECz8oV2GJq2QxQ2w5wKM4EoSfETYJGLaE2mVyczHomoSrLotQpSt2UVTehdFMBnvCEJGiFxhGm9mS3iSkaoiKi-2Mxei~vnexUNqXAw7h10IK11D~YeEitb26DX2IzV9dk~fTaIqKUelwVsP8UHoEGZAaKo-Ss39fi4UpM1jSyH-Oh1hlq4QPD5uyKiEP1L16fHmcnGuvktRb7cIp3hbkNRKd3UAQ0K9kwnoZyZLtGXBHQRiVGv1DXwyX7ZeszAHLMj2bcC~msp27lNQ-BhxAAnjrpTo6VFy2BkCc6AroEMlvbTt-GA~ibcso~VTeyT6aDbvnRBbtUYsLQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Directions of reduced shears for image\u00a0A (red line), image\u00a0B (yellow line), and image\u00a0C (green line) starting at the anchor point of each multiple image as obtained from Table\u00a04 (left). The crossings give a rough estimate of the extension of the critical curve for the source redshift of 0.82. The figure is stretched E-W relative to N-S by a factor of 2 in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103684/stab1375fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103684\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&Signature=cx5bEfjDxFUoXcQRVpNvPlButLsBhXGMA38uCsDjbWu5Fp3CBZLerucLzjxcmy5xcxRkl4oZtn2tpaYLMARQeV7fetqWBrnZOSnexQdnTDaTIgSxV2jbncgCa-QhIUZLcGCW~s41EYRiIRw9JyhxkNOgUDr0zoLdfwYZnCpBH-nJA8r8NGejA0Qq3t0HYZxZgRSqETC7wop1MTraziRSxtVVqZWOmiJILhEoMTvZWIAolHTO5niakQlxtNmFaNndE2zTPxmSu9ad9UH3kFNY2RFQ0oP1wz6c2LT~UoKulN7vflmzVSn6rQ1WtGuvnzOE-JqLKTxuhn2yL1IMPT-sDg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103684&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Directions of reduced shears for image\u00a0<em>A</em> (red line), image\u00a0<em>B</em> (yellow line), and image\u00a0<em>C</em> (green line) starting at the anchor point of each multiple image as obtained from Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left). The crossings give a rough estimate of the extension of the critical curve for the source redshift of 0.82. The figure is stretched E-W relative to N-S by a factor of 2 in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=pr-au7o4ECz8oV2GJq2QxQ2w5wKM4EoSfETYJGLaE2mVyczHomoSrLotQpSt2UVTehdFMBnvCEJGiFxhGm9mS3iSkaoiKi-2Mxei~vnexUNqXAw7h10IK11D~YeEitb26DX2IzV9dk~fTaIqKUelwVsP8UHoEGZAaKo-Ss39fi4UpM1jSyH-Oh1hlq4QPD5uyKiEP1L16fHmcnGuvktRb7cIp3hbkNRKd3UAQ0K9kwnoZyZLtGXBHQRiVGv1DXwyX7ZeszAHLMj2bcC~msp27lNQ-BhxAAnjrpTo6VFy2BkCc6AroEMlvbTt-GA~ibcso~VTeyT6aDbvnRBbtUYsLQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Directions of reduced shears for image\u00a0A (red line), image\u00a0B (yellow line), and image\u00a0C (green line) starting at the anchor point of each multiple image as obtained from Table\u00a04 (left). The crossings give a rough estimate of the extension of the critical curve for the source redshift of 0.82. The figure is stretched E-W relative to N-S by a factor of 2 in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103684/stab1375fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103684\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&Signature=cx5bEfjDxFUoXcQRVpNvPlButLsBhXGMA38uCsDjbWu5Fp3CBZLerucLzjxcmy5xcxRkl4oZtn2tpaYLMARQeV7fetqWBrnZOSnexQdnTDaTIgSxV2jbncgCa-QhIUZLcGCW~s41EYRiIRw9JyhxkNOgUDr0zoLdfwYZnCpBH-nJA8r8NGejA0Qq3t0HYZxZgRSqETC7wop1MTraziRSxtVVqZWOmiJILhEoMTvZWIAolHTO5niakQlxtNmFaNndE2zTPxmSu9ad9UH3kFNY2RFQ0oP1wz6c2LT~UoKulN7vflmzVSn6rQ1WtGuvnzOE-JqLKTxuhn2yL1IMPT-sDg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103684&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Directions of reduced shears for image\u00a0<em>A</em> (red line), image\u00a0<em>B</em> (yellow line), and image\u00a0<em>C</em> (green line) starting at the anchor point of each multiple image as obtained from Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left). The crossings give a rough estimate of the extension of the critical curve for the source redshift of 0.82. The figure is stretched E-W relative to N-S by a factor of 2 in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Without a fourth counter-image on the opposite side of the cluster centre, we cannot constrain the overall projected mass in the area on the sky enclosed by the multiple images. The object at RA 22<sup>h</sup>30<sup>m</sup>07<sup>s</sup>.25 and Dec. \u22128\u00b09\u203218\u2033.17 is a potential candidate for the fourth image but has not been measured spectroscopically because it fell outside the KCWI field of view.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lastly, we reconstruct the critical curve between images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> from the features marked in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. We first apply the approach outlined in Wagner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for all matching features 1\u20136 and subsequently for all seven features, such that the position of the critical curve is given as the mean position between the positions of corresponding features in the two images. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> (left) shows the resulting positions as white circles. Using the features 1\u20136 to determine local lens properties across the entire area covered by the multiple image on the sky, we implicitly assume that these lens properties hardly change over the area enclosed by the features. Thus, the points can be fitted by a line and thereby approximate the critical curve between the images, as the solid white line in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> shows. The approximation has quite tight confidence bounds, indicated by the 68\u00a0per\u2009cent and 95\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence bounds marked by the dashed white and dashed grey lines, respectively. The linear approximation to the critical curve is also extended to investigate how well the estimate of the critical curve position determined from feature\u00a07 matches the linear approximation set up by features\u00a01\u20136. We read off Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> (left) that is still at the boundary of the 95\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence bound. The linear approximation to the critical curve based on all seven features is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> (right) for comparison. While the residual norm per feature point pair from image\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> for the former reconstruction is 0.46, it amounts to 0.54 for this approximation. Hence, the fit only deteriorates slightly.</p>                        <a id=\"269103688\" scrollto-destination=\"269103688\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=N8sU7a8vdJK7mcybWZL8HgA01FrI-9EY4eWBqbfMqSqZawKE3mCQA1Q33cgPTyB2nHo1HLMbtlVYZmvs4G1A4qM~JqbuHwufJooSw9sb8D0W5~FWV8XdhUvGyHhGh6gNnDmL6tYPjc678LYZe7xeT42oeVHNyY51ya9Vi9HvxviBrQ~DyAamDsFgWjrGdbKwxU78x9CatKiMi4hP9xsJruwXKK9I4ciNMVb15gueH-C1oOwviW~~SYfZ05Xh-YRBx1wFQwQY~S5HCIuB03Keybl7ELrpc-1nzJnBkCPAkIt0YGD7LrmcwgbwCurdNDcNAFD86iU4v~JBg4tXrK8yag__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Reconstruction of the critical curve between images\u00a0A and B based on features\u00a01\u20136 (left) and based on all seven features (right): all points on the critical curve determined from the respective (white circles) are fitted to a linear approximation of the critical curve (solid white line) and its confidence bounds given at 68\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence level (dashed white line) and at 95\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence level (dashed grey line). The figure is stretched E-W by a factor of 3 relative to N-S in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103688/stab1375fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103688\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&Signature=BLnSrSzqwhgPbVohFharBpJG8UHPXBd70Dy2YlDF9hHN7AKanDBHcqcmtGAI7VVFipKAy1sTIh1hhgMmUQ9wFbCBDvqspqF~WnRHs13GmAYrOYdI-TVG29JbC~O6gIMwmw3Fdkl4M7GTJsdk6eQ70hi8zHZDiT8z1oKqtLeaR90YRbcjqcjHHZndqk4edPsranB2m2cwGBqVjwQGGxrFRedi2uhgl8kDVDk~b1cZTjWUfUnONzUShXNs-Oc0-wmiKRvASI9HSI9gjKiILndSWvsVwGTBz8BE4KAdzGisQCg53oJBkZK3aVYy~LYi6hYWkAN-x8qpxQtjZRnUP7YlRQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103688&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Reconstruction of the critical curve between images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> based on features\u00a01\u20136 (left) and based on all seven features (right): all points on the critical curve determined from the respective (white circles) are fitted to a linear approximation of the critical curve (solid white line) and its confidence bounds given at 68\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence level (dashed white line) and at 95\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence level (dashed grey line). The figure is stretched E-W by a factor of 3 relative to N-S in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=N8sU7a8vdJK7mcybWZL8HgA01FrI-9EY4eWBqbfMqSqZawKE3mCQA1Q33cgPTyB2nHo1HLMbtlVYZmvs4G1A4qM~JqbuHwufJooSw9sb8D0W5~FWV8XdhUvGyHhGh6gNnDmL6tYPjc678LYZe7xeT42oeVHNyY51ya9Vi9HvxviBrQ~DyAamDsFgWjrGdbKwxU78x9CatKiMi4hP9xsJruwXKK9I4ciNMVb15gueH-C1oOwviW~~SYfZ05Xh-YRBx1wFQwQY~S5HCIuB03Keybl7ELrpc-1nzJnBkCPAkIt0YGD7LrmcwgbwCurdNDcNAFD86iU4v~JBg4tXrK8yag__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Reconstruction of the critical curve between images\u00a0A and B based on features\u00a01\u20136 (left) and based on all seven features (right): all points on the critical curve determined from the respective (white circles) are fitted to a linear approximation of the critical curve (solid white line) and its confidence bounds given at 68\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence level (dashed white line) and at 95\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence level (dashed grey line). The figure is stretched E-W by a factor of 3 relative to N-S in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103688/stab1375fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103688\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&Signature=BLnSrSzqwhgPbVohFharBpJG8UHPXBd70Dy2YlDF9hHN7AKanDBHcqcmtGAI7VVFipKAy1sTIh1hhgMmUQ9wFbCBDvqspqF~WnRHs13GmAYrOYdI-TVG29JbC~O6gIMwmw3Fdkl4M7GTJsdk6eQ70hi8zHZDiT8z1oKqtLeaR90YRbcjqcjHHZndqk4edPsranB2m2cwGBqVjwQGGxrFRedi2uhgl8kDVDk~b1cZTjWUfUnONzUShXNs-Oc0-wmiKRvASI9HSI9gjKiILndSWvsVwGTBz8BE4KAdzGisQCg53oJBkZK3aVYy~LYi6hYWkAN-x8qpxQtjZRnUP7YlRQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103688&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Reconstruction of the critical curve between images\u00a0<em>A</em> and <em>B</em> based on features\u00a01\u20136 (left) and based on all seven features (right): all points on the critical curve determined from the respective (white circles) are fitted to a linear approximation of the critical curve (solid white line) and its confidence bounds given at 68\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence level (dashed white line) and at 95\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence level (dashed grey line). The figure is stretched E-W by a factor of 3 relative to N-S in order to clarify the appearance of the surface brightness features.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We conclude that the DM distribution is homogeneous on arcsecond length scales (6\u00a0kpc) at the positions of the multiple images, otherwise <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> could not have found such a consistent solution. Gradients in the DM densities, originating from small-scale DM inhomogeneities on sub-arcsec. scales cannot be resolved at present. Andrade et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) have used strongly lensed images in eight galaxy clusters to measure DM density profiles over the scale of 10\u2013100\u00a0kpc.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103691 id=\"269103691\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-5>5.5 Source reconstruction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to further cross-check the resulting local lens properties, we use the software package <span class=\"small-caps\">scrim</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> to back-project each multiple image back to the source plane by means of its magnification matrix <em>M<sub>i</sub></em> (see equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ4\"></span><a href=\"#equ4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>)). As the approach only constrains the ratios of convergences, the source can only be reconstructed up to an overall scale factor. The latter is chosen such that <em>M<sub>A</sub></em> has unit determinant. Using the local lens properties of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left), we arrive at the three source reconstructions shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>. The reconstructions based on Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (right) look very similar and are omitted, as the fit to the observations was slightly worse and biased compared to the local lens properties of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left).</p>                        <a id=\"269103694\" scrollto-destination=\"269103694\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img
