class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Back-projections of each multiple image\u00a0<em>A</em> to <em>C</em> (from left to right) to the source plane to obtain a reconstruction of the common source based on the local lens properties of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&amp;Signature=v8dHBMVKE8XsQFSatz-4aaU4UHojFEEA9DnxiRMiHdujTXXg9tX7iHIf~UDBJtjMMC7JAMOPcmUuhSvE9Q6Ix00iYebTbylQnk1UgQY~xysZuJSo03TlgqOccKR3dsjr5BxHsWLWv4Y6f-M26A96pAKSYtnnnmuDKWMTS5KkAsY93~3j4RtkOYtJVeZllaW4fPEytIMLsIp54BXh1T95aKSQtZxcIJJ2BDM8Sc~LC9v65KjRqD~INpgfH2PiUAbM8T9U432MMeRsjCG96an83dt2jBfpw-Y3k646LX3CvIrAoVwfl3SlXTfG4gZx4GB1O7br-u12mnAEX0YIeFmp6A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Back-projections of each multiple image\u00a0A to C (from left to right) to the source plane to obtain a reconstruction of the common source based on the local lens properties of Table\u00a04 (left).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig15.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103694/stab1375fig15.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig15.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103694\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639081232&Signature=cKcDZ8f4u8GEAIcrF7N0SBGNJ0NjgIXj-nCRV2akgRwolWegpA9bqvunvAAuREbyt9oyas25gQyLOzGNdHK8XiZ80del46FT4PIzNTfl7Wks51pEWGBmkWnQrRifpHlQkuCULf7BKhuyuJeRfb8ZUKnOuw3I76c5-C5D0QsA107Q5SFcnfBQIX8YqjCulFVFMukGmRqLAsYzaZ~qly70uNTR~OStCPvgdtN2Q~Hyuhd0X03OVYOZKoyLVDJHkpQ25Mc9cZ4WHC3bD9J8q~bC9oSbWbYYdEhcAvoEEtoBAjzPWXBe-gJ9dHSX4wao2OR7KFy2kgNKOMexiZrLrZibQQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103694&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Back-projections of each multiple image\u00a0<em>A</em> to <em>C</em> (from left to right) to the source plane to obtain a reconstruction of the common source based on the local lens properties of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (left).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">All three back-projections show a high degree of coincidence from visual comparison. A detailed astrophysical analysis of the source object is impeded by the low resolution of the reconstruction, which is based on the pixel-wise back-projection of the image data and does not make any additional assumptions about the morphology or the degree of smoothness of the source surface brightness profile. Hence, the reconstructions in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a> represent the information on arcsecond scales contained in the surface brightness profiles of the multiple images that is common to all approaches with refined, additional assumptions.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103696 id=\"269103696\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 A SERENDIPITOUS LYMAN\u00a0\u03b1 BLOB AT Z \u00a0=\u00a03.2</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the KCWI spectral datacube, a strong Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emission feature was found \u00a08.2 arcseconds to the west of the main lensed images A and B, at RA 22<sup>h</sup>30<sup>m</sup>9<sup>s</sup>.03, Dec. \u22128\u00b09\u203242\u2033.7. The single emission-line feature, at an observed wavelength of 5106 \u00c5, is identified as a Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 blob (LAB) at redshift 3.199\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.001, following the original discovery of such objects by Steidel, Adelberger\u00a0&amp; Shapley (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; see also Francis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) and their subsequent detections in data from instruments such as the Subaru Prime Focus Camera (Matsuda et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and MUSE (Vanzella et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 blob has dimensions of 4 arcsec N-S and 3 arcsec. E-W, i.e. 30 \u00d7 23\u00a0kpc, comparable with similar objects found by Matsuda et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). The observed Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 flux is \u223c1.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221216</sup> ergs cm<sup>\u22122</sup> s<sup>\u22121</sup> as measured in the KCWI, and at the observed redshift of 3.2, this would imply a luminosity of 1.3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>43</sup> ergs s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The object may be magnified by the gravitational potential of the galaxy cluster, however. In common with other LAB\u2019s, we assume that this object is a gaseous hydrogen halo surrounding a young cluster of starbursting galaxies and/or AGN (Geach et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), although the interpretations for LAB\u2019s are split between hyperwind activity from starburst galaxies and inflowing gas (see e.g. Ao et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>)). The LAB is not detected in any of the <em>HST</em> images to limiting magnitudes of \u00a027 in F606W and 26 in F160W.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Further observations of this and other LAB\u2019s are required.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103700 id=\"269103700\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In a <em>HST</em> observation of an x-ray selected AGN, we have serendipitously discovered an unusual gravitationally lensed image configuration which, for the source redshift, is interpreted as a fold image configuration straddling a critical curve caused by a foreground cluster of galaxies, where the cluster mass is about 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, and the cluster contains about 60 <em>L</em>* galaxies, far less than some of the clusters previously characterized via lensing such as those in the CLASH and Hubble Frontiers Fields. The redMaPPer cluster, at a redshift of 0.526, is identified with the faint <em>ROSAT</em> x-ray source 1RXS J222956.9-080823. In addition to the fold pair of images, we identify a candidate third or counterimage as a large clumpy disc galaxy at a redshift of 0.8200. The lensed system is very similar to system #12 of Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have followed the observation-based analysis of Wagner\u00a0&amp; Tessore (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and Wagner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) to constrain the properties of the cluster lens. The DM distribution is homogeneous on arcsecond length scales at the positions of the multiple images, otherwise the <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> software could not have found such a consistent solution. Gradients in the DM density, originating from small-scale DM inhomogeneities on sub-arcsec scales (&lt;6\u00a0kpc) cannot be resolved.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Such gravitationally folded galaxy images, straddling a critical curve caused by a galaxy cluster, are extremely valuable for investigations of the clumping of DM via microlensing of individual supergiant stars or asymmetries in the surface brightness distributions of lensed components. Individual Population III stars and their stellar-mass black hole accretion discs may possibly be studied using JWST through cluster caustic transits (Windhorst et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Further observations are needed to identify other lensed images caused by the cluster and to further characterize the cluster. Monitoring with future large telescopes could be very fruitful.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103705 id=\"269103705\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title js-splitscreen-backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This research is based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> obtained from the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS5-26555. The original <em>HST</em> observations are associated with program GO-13305. Observations have also been obtained from the Hubble Legacy Archive, which is a collaboration between the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI/NASA), the Space Telescope European Coordinating Facility (ST-ECF/ESAC/ESA) and the Canadian Astronomy Data Centre (CADC/NRC/CSA). In particular, data were obtained from <em>HST</em> programs GO-13671 and GO-14098. Support for Program GO-13305 was provided by NASA through a grant from the Space Telescope Science Institute.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A crucial part of the data presented herein were obtained at the W. M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership between the California Institute of Technology, the University of California and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W. M. Keck Foundation. Observations presented here have included results from the KCWI and NIRC2 instruments, under programs H305 and H315, part of the observing time allotment made by the University of Hawaii system (and the Institute of Astronomy) to U Hawaii, Hilo for educational and research training purposes following the decommissioning and removal of the UH Hilo teaching telescope from the summit of Mauna Kea. We greatly appreciate the help of Luca Rizzi with the calibrations and observations. Data from the KCWI were analysed using the KCWI Data Reduction Pipeline.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results presented here are also partly based on observations obtained at the international Gemini Observatory, a program of the NSF NOIRLab, which is managed by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy (AURA) under a cooperative agreement with the National Science Foundation on behalf of the Gemini Observatory partnership. Gemini data were obtained in 2017 and 2018 under programme number GN-2017A-Q-48 which was also part of the observing time allotment made by the University of Hawaii system (and the Institute of Astronomy) to U Hawaii, Hilo for educational and research training purposes following the decommissioning and removal of the UH Hilo teaching telescope from the summit of Mauna Kea. We acknowledge the help of Andrew Stephens with the queue-scheduled observations. Gemini data were analysed using the GMOS-N and the NIRC-2 data reduction and analysis pipelines, operated within IDL.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have made use of the following databases: the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST); the SDSS, Data Release 12; the Pan-STARRS survey archived at the Hubble Legacy Archive, the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED), and NASA\u2019s Astrophysics Data System Abstract Service (ADS).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This research has also made use of data and/or software provided by the High Energy Astrophysics Science Archive Research Center (HEASARC), which is a service of the Astrophysics Science Division at NASA/GSFC.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All spectra presented here were produced using SAOImage DS9, for which development has been made possible by funding from NASA\u2019s Applied Information Systems Research Program, Chandra X-ray Science Center (CXC), and the High Energy Astrophysics Science Archive Center (HEASARC). Additional funding was provided by the James Webb Space Telescope Mission office at Space Telescope Science Institute to improve capabilities for 3D data visualization.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Pan-STARRS1 Surveys (PS1) and the PS1 public science archive have been made possible through contributions by the Institute for Astronomy, the University of Hawaii, the Pan-STARRS Project Office, the Max-Planck Society and its participating institutes, the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, Heidelberg and the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics, Garching, The Johns Hopkins University, Durham University, the University of Edinburgh, the Queen\u2019s University Belfast, the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, the Las Cumbres Observatory Global Telescope Network Incorporated, the National Central University of Taiwan, the Space Telescope Science Institute, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration under grant no. NNX08AR22G issued through the Planetary Science Division of the NASA Science Mission Directorate, the National Science Foundation grant no. AST-1238877, the University of Maryland, Eotvos Lorand University (ELTE), the Los Alamos National Laboratory, and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for the SDSS IV has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science, and the Participating Institutions. SDSS-IV acknowledges support and resources from the Center for High Performance Computing at the University of Utah. The SDSS website is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org\" target=\"_blank\">www.sdss.org</a>. SDSS-IV is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS Collaboration q.v.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We would like to thank Nicolas Tessore for his open source lens reconstruction programs and Adi Zitrin and Liliya Williams for useful comments. JW gratefully acknowledges the support by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG) WA3547/1- 3. We thank the Bologna Lens Factory, and in particular Massimo Meneghetti, for providing us with the <em>Hera</em> simulation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">REG acknowledges receipt of a grant from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Astrophysics Data Analysis Program (NX15AE61G) to the Research Corporation of the University of Hawaii from 2015 to 2018, when the initial stages of this work were performed. Po-Chieh Huang acknowledges support for his undergraduate research work at the University of Hawaii, Hilo, while on an exchange studentship from Chung Yuan Christian University, Taiwan.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Maunakea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain, using both the Gemini-North and Keck telescopes.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103718 id=\"269103718\" class=\"backsection-title js-splitscreen-backsection-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>DATA AVAILABILITY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>HST</em> and Pan-STARRS PS1 data used here are available from the Hubble Legacy Archive at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://hla.stsci.edu\" target=\"_blank\">https://hla.stsci.edu</a>, using the coordinates in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The Gemini spectroscopic data from GMOS-N are available from <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://archive.gemini.edu\" target=\"_blank\">https://archive.gemini.edu</a> under PI Griffiths, with Data Label G-2017A-Q-48.... The Keck Observatory data used here will be available in September 2021 from <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www2.keck.hawaii.edu/koa/public/koa.php\" target=\"_blank\">https://www2.keck.hawaii.edu/koa/public/koa.php</a> and are available prior to that on reasonable request from the corresponding author. The software package <span class=\"small-caps\">ptmatch</span> is available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/ntessore/imagemap\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/ntessore/imagemap</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103721 id=\"269103721\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title             </span>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n<div class=\"pub-history-wrap clearfix js-history-dropdown-wrap\">\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row href='https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stab1375'>https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stab1375</a></div>\r\n        </div>\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row clearfix\">\r\n            <div class=\"ww-citation-date-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"citation-label\">Published:</div>\r\n                <div class=\"citation-date\">17 May 2021</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"history-label js-history-dropdown-trigger st-article-history at-ArticleHistory\">\r\n                    <span>Article history</span><i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n        </div>\r\n            <div class=\"ww-history js-history-entries-wrap at-history-entries-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"history-entry at-history-entry\">\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-state\">Received:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">19 March 2021</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"history-entry at-history-entry\">\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-state\">Revision received:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">07 May 2021</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"history-entry at-history-entry\">\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-state\">Accepted:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">07 May 2021</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"history-entry at-history-entry\">\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-state\">Published:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">17 May 2021</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<script>\r\n    $(document).ready(function () {\r\n class=\"toolbar-wrap js-toolbar-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"toolbar-inner-wrap\">\r\n                    <ul id=\"Toolbar\" role=\"navigation\">\r\n    <li class=\"toolbar-item item-pdf js-item-pdf\">\r\n        <a class=\"al-link pdf article-pdfLink\" data-article-id=\"6276726\" href=\"/mnras/article-pdf/506/2/1595/38969061/stab1375.pdf\">\r\n            <img src=//oup.silverchair-cdn.com/UI/app/svg/pdf.svg alt=\"pdf\" /><span class=\"pdf-link-text\">PDF</span>\r\n        </a>\r\n    </li>\r\n                                                    <li class=\"toolbar-item item-link item-split-view\">\r\n                                <a href=\"javascript:;\"\r\n                                   class=\"split-view js-split-view st-split-view at-split-view\"\r\n                                   target=\"\">\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-menu-split\"></i>\r\n                                    Split View\r\n                                </a>\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-with-dropdown item-views\">\r\n                            <a class=\"at-views-dropdown drop-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-dropdown=\"FilterDrop\" aria-haspopup=\"true\">\r\n                                <i class=\"icon-menu_views\"></i>\r\n                                <div class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                            </a>\r\n                            <ul id=\"ViewsDrop\" class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"article-content\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Article                  <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"video\">\r\n                                    <a class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"supplementary-data\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Supplementary class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Richard E Griffiths, Mitchell Rudisel, Jenny Wagner, Timothy Hamilton, Po-Chieh Huang, Carolin Villforth,  Hamilton\u2019s Object \u2013 a clumpy galaxy straddling the gravitational caustic of a galaxy cluster: constraints on dark matter clumping, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 506, Issue 2, September 2021, Pages 1595\u20131608, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stab1375\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stab1375</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n   <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\"   <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\"       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input        <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103418 id=\"269103418\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery of a \u2018folded\u2019 gravitationally lensed image, \u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019, found in a <em>HST</em> image of the field near the active galactic nucleus SDSS J223010.47-081017.8 (which has redshift 0.62). The lensed images are sourced by a galaxy at a spectroscopic redshift of 0.8200\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0005 and form a fold configuration on a caustic caused by a foreground galaxy cluster at a photometric redshift of 0.526\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.018 seen in the corresponding Pan-STARRS PS1 image and marginally detected as a faint <em>ROSAT</em> All-Sky Survey X-ray source. The lensed images exhibit properties similar to those of other \u2018folds\u2019 where the source galaxy falls very close to or straddles the caustic of a galaxy cluster. The folded images are stretched in a direction roughly orthogonal to the critical curve, but the configuration is that of a tangential cusp. Guided by morphological features, published simulations and similar \u2018fold\u2019 observations in the literature, we identify a third or \u2018counter\u2019-image, confirmed by spectroscopy. Because the fold-configuration shows highly distinctive surface brightness features, follow-up observations of microlensing or detailed investigations of the individual surface brightness features at higher resolution can further shed light on kpc-scale dark matter properties. We determine the local lens properties at the positions of the multiple images according to the observation-based lens reconstruction of Wagner. The analysis is in accordance with a mass density which hardly varies on an arcsecond scale (6\u00a0kpc) over the areas covered by the multiple images.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103420 id=\"269103420\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Light of all wavelengths responds to the curvature of spacetime, which in turn depends on matter and energy content. One outcome of this response is gravitational lensing (for an introduction, see Kochanek, Schneider &amp; Wambsganss (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)), and the study of extragalactic gravitationally lensed objects has become a very fruitful field of research over the past few decades. These studies started with the startling discovery of multiply imaged quasars (Walsh, Carswell\u00a0&amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>), and the general subject of extragalactic lensing has since diversified into a number of extremely active and productive areas, including lensing by large-scale structures, e.g. the Kilo-degree Survey (Tr\u00f6ster et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>) and the Dark Energy Survey (To et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>); clusters of galaxies (Soucail et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>; Kneib &amp; Natarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; the Cluster Lensing and Supernova Survey with Hubble (CLASH; Merten et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>); and the Reionization Lensing Cluster Survey (RELICS; Coe et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and individual galaxies: measurement of H<sub>0</sub> via time-delay cosmography (e.g. Millon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Over the last decade, the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> has been used to determine the mass distribution in clusters of galaxies via the characterization of the multiple lensed systems found in each of the massive clusters studied (these large projects have included the Hubble Frontier Fields: Lotz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; the CLASH survey; and the Beyond Ultra-Deep Frontier Fields and Legacy Observations survey: Steinhardt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Lens reconstruction algorithms have been used to infer the masses and other properties of these clusters: see Meneghetti et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for an overview and a benchmark of common approaches. The resulting masses have been compared with the masses inferred from X-ray observations to study the central parts of the cluster and its relaxation state. Weak gravitational lensing reconstructions in the outer cluster regions complete the reconstruction of the mass-density profile of a galaxy cluster. Constraints on the properties of dark matter (DM) afforded by gravitational lensing have been reviewed by Massey, Kitching\u00a0&amp; Richard (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper describes a strong gravitational-lensing configuration, \u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019, consisting of two resolved images of a clumpy spiral background galaxy in a fold configuration and a third resolved image of the same spiral galaxy, which together create a tangential cusp configuration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The importance of this discovery is in the potential for constraining small-scale DM properties using the highly resolved multiple image configuration straddling the critical curve. Analysis of the individual features observed in the multiple images or the detection of microlensing events on top of the galaxy-cluster-scale magnification effect make such fold configurations ideal probes of DM properties. Future goals could include the investigation of the abundance and distribution of possible compact halo objects or ultralight axion DM.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103424 id=\"269103424\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A complex of folded, distorted, and stretched gravitationally lensed images (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) has been discovered in a <em>HST</em> WFC3 image (P.I. Villforth, Program GO 13305) of the field around the active galactic nucleus (AGN) SDSS J223010.47-081017.8, an AGN possibly identified with the marginally detected <em>ROSAT</em> All Sky Survey source RASS 1RXS J223011.3-081024 (from Anderson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, listed as RASS 6135 in Villforth et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The complex lensed images are surrounded by a cluster of galaxies evident in the Pan-STARRS PS1 images archived at the Hubble Legacy Archive (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://hla.stsci.edu\" target=\"_blank\">https://hla.stsci.edu</a>), and also in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). The SDSS cluster is catalogued as Red Mapper Cluster RM J223013.1-080853.1 (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/\" target=\"_blank\">http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/</a>). redMaPPer is an optical cluster finder based on the detection of spatial overdensities of red sequence galaxies (Wechsler et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Rykoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, McClintock et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). The cluster also appears in the Wavelet Z Photometric catalogue (q.v.: Aguena et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>) in which overdensities are found based on redshifts rather than colours.</p>                        <a id=\"269103426\" scrollto-destination=\"269103426\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=3vsuUGSVOzORuRqmxHMMNr3D0BLYaIl8nDOEuow0cImZ8817MHgdGrJGUBDWWCM7h3J3mpN8s6y2qWSbH-sU0w6qay4jL3gmvhHKBCtdO4L2UWurOkm8Tv7p9PfCxTDXyk-obl4fmSuf2Sy3R5WA1er1RJPCH6M39uzCm4wXQcSRrkC8hTSc2RU3P1af2IfPogP6qKpOkY9c9~E620yCU9LijHRd6r1-BlCJbDElanQsJJYY-iD8W7DFt1QYTCmh9fmeLS4wJ4glFVndF8mM3~AplwGWAALTGSTKAVsLmHWxHeyHlmLfBHqaJ~wRREu5lQL5gfCLWsP0Koooub4TJw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019: the HST WFC3 H-band image (3 \u00d7 700\u2009s). The scale bar is 10 arc secs.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103426/stab1375fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103426\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=I8bBzU0apJHEU6SgkI8dz9EKowCwm6uPiR4UePmCFaJKFkic0FNAe9CqfRylsIjoO2o9fHWr5oLFcQlBjLFJuNfUKINaj6FVMF9PX0G18XH-rBWQEJGVy1zqzirFYNMMfNz5peY199B8ozF~u~W3vt90t9Lz~uQwkkTHggAz03OrT09ix7rEQ6KW5sv-2Xzy8itb82n~x~u7fiYunzYssoiJrPcfVtohDfN-KrzFIIkCiBV0SHeY2anvKkBohWyFqyCxtLHj3Xi8DeuPOx5jSsTdlgI-RLYpX95J~zp7YMVRgPlhU3rXYGsgtzZ-gGQ7ZjpR6jJPJPPPQRef1kU6yg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103426&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019: the <em>HST</em> WFC3 H-band image (3 \u00d7 700\u2009s). The scale bar is 10 arc secs.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=3vsuUGSVOzORuRqmxHMMNr3D0BLYaIl8nDOEuow0cImZ8817MHgdGrJGUBDWWCM7h3J3mpN8s6y2qWSbH-sU0w6qay4jL3gmvhHKBCtdO4L2UWurOkm8Tv7p9PfCxTDXyk-obl4fmSuf2Sy3R5WA1er1RJPCH6M39uzCm4wXQcSRrkC8hTSc2RU3P1af2IfPogP6qKpOkY9c9~E620yCU9LijHRd6r1-BlCJbDElanQsJJYY-iD8W7DFt1QYTCmh9fmeLS4wJ4glFVndF8mM3~AplwGWAALTGSTKAVsLmHWxHeyHlmLfBHqaJ~wRREu5lQL5gfCLWsP0Koooub4TJw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019: the HST WFC3 H-band image (3 \u00d7 700\u2009s). The scale bar is 10 arc secs.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103426/stab1375fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103426\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=I8bBzU0apJHEU6SgkI8dz9EKowCwm6uPiR4UePmCFaJKFkic0FNAe9CqfRylsIjoO2o9fHWr5oLFcQlBjLFJuNfUKINaj6FVMF9PX0G18XH-rBWQEJGVy1zqzirFYNMMfNz5peY199B8ozF~u~W3vt90t9Lz~uQwkkTHggAz03OrT09ix7rEQ6KW5sv-2Xzy8itb82n~x~u7fiYunzYssoiJrPcfVtohDfN-KrzFIIkCiBV0SHeY2anvKkBohWyFqyCxtLHj3Xi8DeuPOx5jSsTdlgI-RLYpX95J~zp7YMVRgPlhU3rXYGsgtzZ-gGQ7ZjpR6jJPJPPPQRef1kU6yg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103426&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019: the <em>HST</em> WFC3 H-band image (3 \u00d7 700\u2009s). The lensed images are encircled. The halfway point between the two brightest lensed image components is at RA 22<sup>h</sup>30<sup>m</sup>9<sup>s</sup>.7, Dec. \u221208<sup>o</sup>09\u203240\u2033 (J2000). The scale bar is 10 arc secs.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103427 id=\"269103427\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 X-ray detection of the galaxy cluster</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Thus far, there have been no pointed (or slew-survey) x-ray observations of the cluster using XMM-Newton or the Chandra X-ray Observatory. But, as well as <em>ROSAT</em> detection of the nearby AGN, the cluster was marginally detected in the <em>ROSAT</em> All Sky Survey (RASS) as x-ray source 1RXS \u00a0J222956.9-080823 (Voges et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) with x-ray countrate 3.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.7\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22122</sup> counts s<sup>\u22121</sup> corresponding to a flux of 3.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221213</sup> ergs cm<sup>\u22122</sup> s<sup>\u22121</sup> (0.1\u20132.4 kev). The RASS Faint Source Catalogue (RASSFSC) is included in the second <em>ROSAT</em> All-Sky Survey Catalogue (2RXS: Boller et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) but the 2RXS has only one source in the vicinity of the AGN and the cluster, a source which is assigned a 43\u00a0per\u2009cent probability of extension, with extremely few x-ray counts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The cluster x-ray source was too faint to be included in the <em>ROSAT</em>-ESO Flux-Limited X-ray Galaxy Cluster Survey (REFLEX; B\u00f6hringer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) or in REFLEX II (Chon\u00a0&amp; B\u00f6hringer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), even though those papers addressed clusters in the appropriate redshift range.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Likewise, the cluster is not included in the Master Catalogue of X-ray Selected Clusters (Piffaretti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). With a photometric redshift for the cluster of 0.526\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.018 (redMaPPerClusters \u2013 from SDSS DR8: NASA Extragalactic Database (NED) RM\u00a0J223013.1-080853.1), the X-ray luminosity (taking the 1XRS cluster source flux) is 3.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>44</sup> ergs s<sup>\u22121</sup> (0.5\u20132.4\u00a0keV). Using the correlation between cluster mass and x-ray luminosity found by Stanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), this luminosity would imply an approximate mass of 5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, in the mid-range for clusters.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103434 id=\"269103434\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Optical images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The discovery image of \u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019 in the <em>HST</em> WFC3 H-band is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and the F606W image in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, where the latter image shows structure (superstarburst regions) within 0.2 arcsec to the west of the nuclear bulge. The overall object shows a (roughly north-south) mirror symmetry, with two brighter component images (nuclear bulges), one in each half, and three (split) linear features, spanning a total of about 4 by 6 arcsec. The two brightest central (nuclear bulge) images have F606W magnitudes of \u2243 24 from SExtractor in the <em>HST</em> archive, and each has slightly arced and stretched images to both the east and west. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the Sextractor magnitudes of the central nuclear bulge objects in the <em>HST</em> filters.</p>                        <a id=\"269103439\" scrollto-destination=\"269103439\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=fPsU3QjvuBEX3R4xGHrLJseMH1m11fp2IkCDRqbNFGmYUFE1gFZbPtRzsgVO3ZNk72auXAZ4wttT2o3a6PHb1rH6m2E-9LG2zR4SLZq~jy6mLPbwOJ5wspBut8fH067TN2UNoQJUyArmnRVmSXCp1mQyK~dolPqDR6~r2Q~tInOaLUenjjmO~1Z9W-l7AdxpCpexb7yFwKj61voNhtd7ISGetNzkwG2Vyz84uciCWPZh1Qfe3NvQoIsY32dpjBG6Kp207FmJekHYHSDTCAP9PpGrSzoKOj~bLCRhPOzBKvjY1CetE8o-LQXOodkZWQV84V7w9EHctnd9qdbXn31LvA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The HST ACS/F606W image (3600\u00a0s) showing folded images A and B and third or counterimage C (see Section\u00a03.2). The nuclear bulges are A1, B1, C1, and the surface brightness features of C are labelled 2\u20137, with corresponding features in fold images A and B. These features are seen more clearly in Figs\u00a07 and\u00a012. The overall frame size is 18\u00a0\u00d7\u00a025 arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103439/stab1375fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103439\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=vdMyYtEppMd68fv-tSwxW0C1F60aD9zJTVH51k~OzEtsmnkrLU09x8Dh7Bdl78W-UobIyiIEKrUkzy-w2V6xATIjfiJDtcGB1cRvfoMBNuH5TsQLO5YYQXi6yzXqAfbhLbHmLmn60kEiSPaqZH4MSeFnTs676IBdmcY62q8I-vlOJku9G5sHNpPNpnubol5Id8NH3vD1y6iI6mY3ISWYawwfnnfObKQpyNBjDKAXmeJTFtk7PyFDyfD7VQGjhz6JPDa-qycV8aebH9R6nF9Hl7VH7SlqqBS6OBT1DQIYSDqgcZNn2~2j7lNBTKqjpgT2nsAV6lj085v4mp4zWNIf9g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103439&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>HST</em> ACS/F606W image (3600\u00a0s) showing folded images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> and third or counterimage <em>C</em> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.2</a>). The nuclear bulges are A1, B1, C1, and the surface brightness features of C are labelled 2\u20137, with corresponding features in fold images A and B. These features are seen more clearly in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. The overall frame size is 18\u00a0\u00d7\u00a025 arcsec.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=fPsU3QjvuBEX3R4xGHrLJseMH1m11fp2IkCDRqbNFGmYUFE1gFZbPtRzsgVO3ZNk72auXAZ4wttT2o3a6PHb1rH6m2E-9LG2zR4SLZq~jy6mLPbwOJ5wspBut8fH067TN2UNoQJUyArmnRVmSXCp1mQyK~dolPqDR6~r2Q~tInOaLUenjjmO~1Z9W-l7AdxpCpexb7yFwKj61voNhtd7ISGetNzkwG2Vyz84uciCWPZh1Qfe3NvQoIsY32dpjBG6Kp207FmJekHYHSDTCAP9PpGrSzoKOj~bLCRhPOzBKvjY1CetE8o-LQXOodkZWQV84V7w9EHctnd9qdbXn31LvA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The HST ACS/F606W image (3600\u00a0s) showing folded images A and B and third or counterimage C (see Section\u00a03.2). These features are seen more clearly in Figs\u00a07 and\u00a012. The overall frame size is 18\u00a0\u00d7\u00a025 arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103439/stab1375fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103439\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=vdMyYtEppMd68fv-tSwxW0C1F60aD9zJTVH51k~OzEtsmnkrLU09x8Dh7Bdl78W-UobIyiIEKrUkzy-w2V6xATIjfiJDtcGB1cRvfoMBNuH5TsQLO5YYQXi6yzXqAfbhLbHmLmn60kEiSPaqZH4MSeFnTs676IBdmcY62q8I-vlOJku9G5sHNpPNpnubol5Id8NH3vD1y6iI6mY3ISWYawwfnnfObKQpyNBjDKAXmeJTFtk7PyFDyfD7VQGjhz6JPDa-qycV8aebH9R6nF9Hl7VH7SlqqBS6OBT1DQIYSDqgcZNn2~2j7lNBTKqjpgT2nsAV6lj085v4mp4zWNIf9g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103439&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>HST</em> ACS/F606W image (3600\u00a0s) showing folded images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> and third or counterimage <em>C</em> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.2</a>). The nuclear bulges are A1, B1, C1, and the surface brightness features of C are labelled 2\u20137, with corresponding features in fold images A and B. These features are seen more clearly in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. The overall frame size is 18\u00a0\u00d7\u00a025 arcsec.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"269103446\" scrollto-destination=\"269103446\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Nuclear bulge magnitudes of lensed components (from HLA Sextractor, mag-auto values).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F606W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.17\u00a0</td><td>22.46\u00a0</td><td>21.55\u00a0</td><td>21.29\u00a0</td><td>21.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>B</em>\u00a0</td><td>22.80\u00a0</td><td>22.20\u00a0</td><td>21.22\u00a0</td><td>20.93\u00a0</td><td>20.86\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>C</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.69\u00a0</td><td>23.30\u00a0</td><td>22.13\u00a0</td><td>21.87\u00a0</td><td>21.57\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F606W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.17\u00a0</td><td>22.46\u00a0</td><td>21.55\u00a0</td><td>21.29\u00a0</td><td>21.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>B</em>\u00a0</td><td>22.80\u00a0</td><td>22.20\u00a0</td><td>21.22\u00a0</td><td>20.93\u00a0</td><td>20.86\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>C</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.69\u00a0</td><td>23.30\u00a0</td><td>22.13\u00a0</td><td>21.87\u00a0</td><td>21.57\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/269103446\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Nuclear bulge magnitudes of lensed components (from HLA Sextractor, mag-auto values).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F606W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F814W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F110W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F140W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F160W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.17\u00a0</td><td>22.46\u00a0</td><td>21.55\u00a0</td><td>21.29\u00a0</td><td>21.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>B</em>\u00a0</td><td>22.80\u00a0</td><td>22.20\u00a0</td><td>21.22\u00a0</td><td>20.93\u00a0</td><td>20.86\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>C</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.69\u00a0</td><td>23.30\u00a0</td><td>22.13\u00a0</td><td>21.87\u00a0</td><td>21.57\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F606W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F814W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F110W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F140W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>F160W<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.17\u00a0</td><td>22.46\u00a0</td><td>21.55\u00a0</td><td>21.29\u00a0</td><td>21.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>B</em>\u00a0</td><td>22.80\u00a0</td><td>22.20\u00a0</td><td>21.22\u00a0</td><td>20.93\u00a0</td><td>20.86\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>C</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.69\u00a0</td><td>23.30\u00a0</td><td>22.13\u00a0</td><td>21.87\u00a0</td><td>21.57\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/269103446\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">There is a very high degree of symmetry about a line running through the centre of the whole lensed image at a position angle of about 100 deg (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The original <em>HST</em> WFC3 image (with exposure of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0700\u2009s) was made in 2013 with the infrared F160W (H-band) filter (GO 13305). Since the original <em>HST</em> WFC3 image (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), further observations of this field have been made in 2015 and 2016 under <em>HST</em> snapshot programs GO-13671 and GO-14098 (part of the program of Repp\u00a0&amp; Ebeling <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). These <em>HST</em> snapshot programs included ACS/WFC observations through filters F606W and F814W, and further WFC3 observations using filters F110W and F160W. The ACS/WFC exposures were of duration 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01200\u00a0s in each filter and the additional WFC3 exposures in 2016 were 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0706\u00a0s (F110W) and 4\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01412\u00a0s (F140W). The magnitudes of the nuclear bulge components (in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> etc.) in <em>HST</em> filters are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The snapshot observations were targeted on the X-ray cluster \u2018eMACS J2229.9-0808A\u2019 (see <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://hla.stsci.edu\" target=\"_blank\">https://hla.stsci.edu</a>), corresponding to the marginally detected x-ray source 1RXS J222956.9-080823 in the first version of the RASSFSC.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The main nuclear bulge images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are resolved in the Pan-STARRS PS1 images in the Hubble Legacy Archive, and the combined Pan-STARRS z-r-g image is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. \u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019 is clearly bluer than the cluster galaxies, i.e. the source has ongoing star formation, consistent with a spiral star-forming galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"269103452\" scrollto-destination=\"269103452\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=CnTjc-M5vb-vfZytaWdUrEfVWJCwu36a3Q-6lnCCoSGo63SXnW2FLmBjDkWWD4e~x~WUNI0XjR2H0WmmOU-SeOz7eSa-JdIj1sxVomRSTiN33aGQ6h3Y62fywtcvhJxfWS29Y8hdRK99vJakL5mevfXMAFS0ySVcKD1rui3-RNY5NMQb2f-UzYd9duaRKjqIBwsgRsH-RBnXxAZ3vkc8P7Zh~TqK3JqGzf69MuyxHVHWAQNpMOSyuGvuSEc8d5ZVIYXt~bMc-7yFrqJafSPCeZCmZlpfoXiyiQlAPxDkgqtHVZH~Vw4bXfDyjPQqFhKQE1KB81vz9K82dNkXj0pnaw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS PS1 combined z-r-g image of the galaxy cluster RM J223013.1-080853.1 (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. 2016; http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/) showing the location of the lensed images. RM marks the galaxy found as the cluster \u2018centre\u2019 or brightest cluster galaxy by the rm software. The QSO or AGN is also marked, as are the lensed images A\u00a0&amp; B, which are blue and marginally resolved. The QSO or AGN is also marked, as are the lensed images <em>A</em>\u00a0&amp; <em>B</em>, which are blue and marginally resolved. The approximate location of the local gravitational centre, as determined by lensing analysis (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>) is marked LGC.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=CnTjc-M5vb-vfZytaWdUrEfVWJCwu36a3Q-6lnCCoSGo63SXnW2FLmBjDkWWD4e~x~WUNI0XjR2H0WmmOU-SeOz7eSa-JdIj1sxVomRSTiN33aGQ6h3Y62fywtcvhJxfWS29Y8hdRK99vJakL5mevfXMAFS0ySVcKD1rui3-RNY5NMQb2f-UzYd9duaRKjqIBwsgRsH-RBnXxAZ3vkc8P7Zh~TqK3JqGzf69MuyxHVHWAQNpMOSyuGvuSEc8d5ZVIYXt~bMc-7yFrqJafSPCeZCmZlpfoXiyiQlAPxDkgqtHVZH~Vw4bXfDyjPQqFhKQE1KB81vz9K82dNkXj0pnaw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS PS1 combined z-r-g image of the galaxy cluster RM J223013.1-080853.1 (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. 2016; http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/) showing the location of the lensed images. RM marks the galaxy found as the cluster \u2018centre\u2019 or brightest cluster galaxy by the rm software. The QSO or AGN is also marked, as are the lensed images A\u00a0&amp; B, which are blue and marginally resolved. The approximate location of the local gravitational centre, as determined by lensing analysis (Section\u00a05) is marked LGC.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103452/stab1375fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103452\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=Am2HRM5fEVMDP-j-9-iGIq7cGvyds7Hj6lC74lzjahSBlnmRAu6xwantu0YnuR39-dkXzsX6IBTLxxjlLQZb33Hf0ta-WYbT4do-HS6fFjGUFxMsCLbsNhGYC-Ttw4gvqf1OzQbPqN3Q680eu6naJQtctxDiE~7ERO0RCrs~pxboSy~O9FvcWWmv0sdJbLBD5aIf-4~xk7wa-2copdjYhH8fZreDULusTTJu4dWfqQOvSLq5V-3AyhscVRhVHw6t3aXaTUOk~Elb-X0Z5KkjhZDl5DwIMRdTUxTCb19hsRYaNKZo~Oj9tFNIKTWU3ZNffFSvhzSPkuw9KgTsSzj0Gg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103452&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pan-STARRS PS1 combined z-r-g image of the galaxy cluster RM J223013.1-080853.1 (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/\" target=\"_blank\">http://risa.stanford.edu/redmapper/</a>) showing the location of the lensed images. RM marks the galaxy found as the cluster \u2018centre\u2019 or brightest cluster galaxy by the <span class=\"small-caps\">rm</span> software. The QSO or AGN is also marked, as are the lensed images <em>A</em>\u00a0&amp; <em>B</em>, which are blue and marginally resolved. The approximate location of the local gravitational centre, as determined by lensing analysis (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>) is marked LGC.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Surrounding the lensed images is a galaxy cluster for which the apparent members have SDSS photometric redshifts averaging 0.526\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.018, as measured and catalogued in redMaPPerClusters in the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database, NED: RM J223013.1-080853.1. The redMaPPer catalogue cluster members are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (using the Tool for OPerations on Catalogues And Tables, TOPCAT (Taylor <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>)). There is no core- or central-Dominant (cD) galaxy present, unlike the situation in many richer and more relaxed clusters. The catalogued RM cluster centre is positioned on one of the brightest galaxies, labelled <em>RM</em> in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, but this galaxy is probably not the actual cluster centre, as seen from its peripheral position, and also suggested by our multiple image lensing analysis (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>). This problem of identification of the cluster centre is in common with many RM clusters (Ryckoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The total number of \u2243 <em>L</em>* galaxies is about 60; so, by comparison with other clusters (Andreon\u00a0&amp; Hurn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), we might expect the total cluster mass to be weakly constrained to 3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>.</p>                        <a id=\"269103458\" scrollto-destination=\"269103458\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=aQrzvd7Gu~rM5pHK9DRHkEG6w6Bu2E3QLXxJW~XlIafwqYsh1lP~aQtwEmD7m3ru5ji8QrhyudcYav17z56nTm1BjkHsLjNe-dsgP1dgs0MeAK-HU1Z~5b9VWB-dzgEyvMHLzKbBlX2uDNSjsGdIAn8usxelNLXXXpq7nAdgMZOa3UbLEUMt3UKRSivRkOFku74EHg2W3siIYzSS1FrH74v5Oet2eBsjLmh5OiOyCkEt8dm2obAuSJqG8SitnyEHmtYxwFxmQQqclUUk85MhA84fwFXL0YyxGX1qBk1XAf1mtZfnmNH4MJUeckjXo-z-QYM5X5PYBn5ITxBmuN4tDQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"redMaPPer cluster RM223013.1-080853.1 showing locations of photometric cluster members. The galaxy labelled RM is the one found by redMaPPer as the brightest. The position of lensed fold images A and B (Fig.\u00a01) is marked as L.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103458/stab1375fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103458\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=ZoP0LV5dDRjqF45ZApXDBijFms1ym58yXN6ophGSnDRTncF~-YdBfbkJ7KcoU21HfxRFHCwfwczei4tk4HCSOaAgZz8AoRD7LGiIr4jSZGIEuV10OcGJDvw3~klWwV2-ukzxy-XTiyXpMQA3vJXimPaVgXCyasqSP1IwovF3470jyKxMhc-1EaQZ4524STh-IJzrDSBbKkQ1InCW-G7eRXjG1vhGArYwfkdHUBoyvRs9Q-u4Wek34MopEmn8jaw6skxlNq3ccPVbzSb0EdtQ9aZMMyf-CiPvAQ9GTZ78dLLvI495ZHX05nYK3Ijy50ew2ChiAZk4Qpa2vGAHZpk8Qw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103458&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">redMaPPer cluster RM223013.1-080853.1 showing locations of photometric cluster members. The galaxy labelled RM is the one found by redMaPPer as the brightest. The position of lensed fold images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) is marked as L.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=aQrzvd7Gu~rM5pHK9DRHkEG6w6Bu2E3QLXxJW~XlIafwqYsh1lP~aQtwEmD7m3ru5ji8QrhyudcYav17z56nTm1BjkHsLjNe-dsgP1dgs0MeAK-HU1Z~5b9VWB-dzgEyvMHLzKbBlX2uDNSjsGdIAn8usxelNLXXXpq7nAdgMZOa3UbLEUMt3UKRSivRkOFku74EHg2W3siIYzSS1FrH74v5Oet2eBsjLmh5OiOyCkEt8dm2obAuSJqG8SitnyEHmtYxwFxmQQqclUUk85MhA84fwFXL0YyxGX1qBk1XAf1mtZfnmNH4MJUeckjXo-z-QYM5X5PYBn5ITxBmuN4tDQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"redMaPPer cluster RM223013.1-080853.1 showing locations of photometric cluster members. The position of lensed fold images A and B (Fig.\u00a01) is marked as L.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103458/stab1375fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103458\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=ZoP0LV5dDRjqF45ZApXDBijFms1ym58yXN6ophGSnDRTncF~-YdBfbkJ7KcoU21HfxRFHCwfwczei4tk4HCSOaAgZz8AoRD7LGiIr4jSZGIEuV10OcGJDvw3~klWwV2-ukzxy-XTiyXpMQA3vJXimPaVgXCyasqSP1IwovF3470jyKxMhc-1EaQZ4524STh-IJzrDSBbKkQ1InCW-G7eRXjG1vhGArYwfkdHUBoyvRs9Q-u4Wek34MopEmn8jaw6skxlNq3ccPVbzSb0EdtQ9aZMMyf-CiPvAQ9GTZ78dLLvI495ZHX05nYK3Ijy50ew2ChiAZk4Qpa2vGAHZpk8Qw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103458&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">redMaPPer cluster RM223013.1-080853.1 showing locations of photometric cluster members. The galaxy labelled RM is the one found by redMaPPer as the brightest. The position of lensed fold images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) is marked as L.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">A very faint gravitational arc appears in the <em>HST</em> F606 images, centred at RA 22<sup>h</sup>30<sup>m</sup>08<sup>s</sup>.97, Dec. \u221208\u00b009\u203242\u2033.0, and even more faintly in F814W (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). The arc is apparently split into three parts and possibly indicates that the centre of mass of the cluster is likely somewhere between <em>A</em>/<em>B</em> and counterimage <em>C</em>, but the faint arc may be additionally lensed by a background galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"269103463\" scrollto-destination=\"269103463\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=YzOnYO--6tb4UIODyrhgE-FgCfktIX~0r-9gZpDRvoiQZJFSpbJEvhzbG16m6HWqE8AqEOC2TviFqwgX9382xMgsoU6mD0fXdsu4ba49TsuTdogg79oL8vz4N17myyhIYW9dyDkhPNQVSiAQMOTL5cOsU8UnmSE8BnPVWTyTHP9NFcFVaq9CulSsvlLZbwYhTNVPYVbGm-b281qiLY-TSd749R~HJ6z7P3rOsyrGM9r3OBwVy-EF~K4UJLz5hiKhKdNXKUv8kQD9iH5UUvIG4PujCc63Vd7To0X0zV7LT0VmQrEGEveiQJSuUdHxqnwp6nGow8CJ2nyxH8B4PBRrsA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103463&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\"
