the west of folded images A/B.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=269103474 id=\"269103474\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 FINDING THE THIRD OR \u2018COUNTERIMAGE\u2019</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103511 id=\"269103511\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Comparison with a similar caustic-straddling fold in HFF MACS J0416.1-2403</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">By comparison with similar objects in the <em>HST Frontier Field</em>s (HFF), and in other clusters, and by reference to the theoretical interpretation of Wagner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and Wagner\u00a0&amp; Bartelmann (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), \u2018Hamilton\u2019s Object\u2019 is clearly a gravitationally lensed \u2018fold\u2019 straddling the critical line in the lens plane of a foreground cluster of galaxies (e.g. Keeton, Gaudi\u00a0&amp; Petters <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>; Wagner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>, Tables <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). In the absence of a spectroscopic survey of the cluster and background objects, or spectroscopy of the lensed images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), the <em>HST</em> field images were examined to identify possible candidates for the third or \u2018counterimage\u2019 or other lensed image components.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lensed objects in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> can perhaps best be understood by comparison with lensed system #12 in the Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) paper on the HFF cluster MACS J0416.1-2403. Caminha et\u00a0al.\u2019s system #12 is also system #28 in Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and system #35 in Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). In Caminha et\u00a0al.\u2019s system #12, the source galaxy (an irregular, \u2018stringy\u2019 or \u2018clumpy\u2019 galaxy) has a redshift of 0.94 and its images straddle the corresponding critical line that envelopes the central part of the cluster MACS J0416.3-2403 at redshift z \u00a0=\u00a00.396. Remarkably, an observation has been made that a supergiant on the outskirts of the galaxy has been microlensed and has clearly been greatly magnified during the 2 yr covered by <em>HST</em> observations as it crossed the caustic (discovered independently by Chen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and Kaurov et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>)); the peak magnification factor was about 1000 when all <em>HST</em> observations are included (Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). This transient is within a small fraction of an arcsecond from the critical line (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). In the same HFF field, Rodney et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) detected a pair of transients at two separate locations in a highly magnified galaxy at z \u00a0=\u00a01.01.</p>                        <a id=\"269103517\" scrollto-destination=\"269103517\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=JdnkSxSQtTtrxnMURXmy0YLUJiZzEYSlQjJU4dutDKA~LtqJf~rdXi6bponOEwqFSeqRX43-RZ~jx~6-R0MXKk2TdSJ~2rcoV8WjcXZsChv5TV1ql~os828xFEXbc94aTSqiSA37U-y21NYcnPmsUSq-FsY3ABpmsUTUGHfSUeN8FazGlabhzIY7hx-WW0RMYUT33UZJ~f0l74-lEvRMnxDzxZGDCJTfe23cFaQg-HK037A20-BdxH8gSIBhQi5xZ2qsur~rv4Hlsk~JJ7u39FQegNYSxHYt6grRtzoAaIZUG6XIVdnbBGDmNUCCxG6bfzx-pmx80GAqGwdRB8ovCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Reproduction of Kaurov et\u00a0al. (2019) Fig.\u00a01: Combined false-colour image using the F105W, F814W, and F606W filters showing the region centred on lensed system #12(a,b) in Caminha et\u00a0al. (2017) in MACS J0416.1-2403. The white line is the calculated critical curve for a source redshift z \u00a0=\u00a00.94 (Caminha et\u00a0al. 2017) which almost coincides with the isodensity contour for a projected mass column density of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01015 M\u2299 Mpc\u22122. The transient source (Kaurov et\u00a0al. (2019), Chen et\u00a0al. (2019)) appeared within the blue arc indicated.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103517/stab1375fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103517\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=G23Lh4cp55Aoos4E~f8xdjkntJ84M5qcWPGTCtW0Jgb0v3OINr~e4FLAN1VVTYPmXdOsAOSYBGBWMa5Lk4O1TqTtEA5BGp2wyLLtijXuz-qWXD1Hqoh01EsS288k4xPc~sE5EC1zD8W1CDcyOdP8mxTz0ysDcoqBdgHM9fn668ZCstBsrX4YORVS7SUXEZxEqGLrBDAZiiRi8UxW4B1WsRAm2AafrrGaSfW3YwQFN19fCGHkrikyAmmr9cJuicLt~Zy-FP-3hbjU2LvX~R2f7T90~zX1hbw5vNeItfSvdQiiLFeitQH1iRqkjzKjg1AfYrYMbCXMGIbgS1Od77talA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103517&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Reproduction of Kaurov et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>: Combined false-colour image using the F105W, F814W, and F606W filters showing the region centred on lensed system #12(a,b) in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) in MACS J0416.1-2403. The white line is the calculated critical curve for a source redshift z \u00a0=\u00a00.94 (Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) which almost coincides with the isodensity contour for a projected mass column density of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>15</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> Mpc<sup>\u22122</sup>. The transient source (Kaurov et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), Chen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>)) appeared within the blue arc indicated.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=JdnkSxSQtTtrxnMURXmy0YLUJiZzEYSlQjJU4dutDKA~LtqJf~rdXi6bponOEwqFSeqRX43-RZ~jx~6-R0MXKk2TdSJ~2rcoV8WjcXZsChv5TV1ql~os828xFEXbc94aTSqiSA37U-y21NYcnPmsUSq-FsY3ABpmsUTUGHfSUeN8FazGlabhzIY7hx-WW0RMYUT33UZJ~f0l74-lEvRMnxDzxZGDCJTfe23cFaQg-HK037A20-BdxH8gSIBhQi5xZ2qsur~rv4Hlsk~JJ7u39FQegNYSxHYt6grRtzoAaIZUG6XIVdnbBGDmNUCCxG6bfzx-pmx80GAqGwdRB8ovCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Reproduction of Kaurov et\u00a0al. (2019) Fig.\u00a01: Combined false-colour image using the F105W, F814W, and F606W filters showing the region centred on lensed system #12(a,b) in Caminha et\u00a0al. (2017) in MACS J0416.1-2403. The white line is the calculated critical curve for a source redshift z \u00a0=\u00a00.94 (Caminha et\u00a0al. 2017) which almost coincides with the isodensity contour for a projected mass column density of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01015 M\u2299 Mpc\u22122. The transient source (Kaurov et\u00a0al. (2019), Chen et\u00a0al. (2019)) appeared within the blue arc indicated.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103517/stab1375fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103517\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=G23Lh4cp55Aoos4E~f8xdjkntJ84M5qcWPGTCtW0Jgb0v3OINr~e4FLAN1VVTYPmXdOsAOSYBGBWMa5Lk4O1TqTtEA5BGp2wyLLtijXuz-qWXD1Hqoh01EsS288k4xPc~sE5EC1zD8W1CDcyOdP8mxTz0ysDcoqBdgHM9fn668ZCstBsrX4YORVS7SUXEZxEqGLrBDAZiiRi8UxW4B1WsRAm2AafrrGaSfW3YwQFN19fCGHkrikyAmmr9cJuicLt~Zy-FP-3hbjU2LvX~R2f7T90~zX1hbw5vNeItfSvdQiiLFeitQH1iRqkjzKjg1AfYrYMbCXMGIbgS1Od77talA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103517&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Reproduction of Kaurov et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>: Combined false-colour image using the F105W, F814W, and F606W filters showing the region centred on lensed system #12(a,b) in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) in MACS J0416.1-2403. The white line is the calculated critical curve for a source redshift z \u00a0=\u00a00.94 (Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) which almost coincides with the isodensity contour for a projected mass column density of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>15</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> Mpc<sup>\u22122</sup>. The transient source (Kaurov et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), Chen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>)) appeared within the blue arc indicated.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In an earlier example of this remarkable microlensing phenomenon, Kelly et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) discovered a transient lasting several weeks in a highly magnified galaxy at z \u00a0=\u00a01.49 in another HFF field, MACS J1149.5\u00a0+\u00a02233. The transient object (MACS J1149 Lensed Star 1 (LS1)) was magnified by more than a factor 2000. Venumadhav, Dai\u00a0&amp; Miralda-Escud\u00e9 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) have shown the importance of such microlensing observations for investigations into the substructure of DM. A mass fraction in microlenses causes disruption of the otherwise smooth caustic into a network of corrugated microcaustics and the light curve of a caustic-crossing star is thus broken up into numerous peaks. As shown by these authors, the sensitivity of caustic-crossing events to the granularity of the lens-mass distribution makes them ideal probes of DM structural components, such as compact halo objects or ultralight axion DM. In a similar context, Dai et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) have commented on the possibility that asymmetric surface brightness structure of the caustic crossing arc SGAS J122651.3+215220 in the cluster SDSS J1226\u00a0+\u00a02152 may be evidence for DM substructure with subhaloes of \u223c10<sup>6</sup>\u221210<sup>8</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>. Further, Dai (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>) has shown that star clusters, microlensed in caustic crossings, can result in observable variability in <em>HST</em> and JWST data and that such data can potentially be used to constrain the substructure of the DM. Any flux anomaly in strongly lensed systems can be used to probe subhalos in the lensing galaxies (Dalal\u00a0&amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), and the promise of this technique in future observations from space has been investigated further by Diego (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Dai\u00a0&amp; Miralda-Escud\u00e9 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) have shown that axion minihaloes in galaxy clusters should produce subtle surface density fluctuations of amplitude \u223c10<sup>\u22124</sup>\u221210<sup>\u22123</sup> on projected length scales of \u223c10\u221210<sup>4</sup> AU, which imprint irregularities on the microlensing light curves of caustic transiting stars. As summarized in the \u2018fuzzy\u2019 or \u2018wave\u2019 DM review by Hui (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>), this effect was also used by Gilman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) to constrain warm DM and by Schutz (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) to limit fuzzy DM.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Unlike Caminha et\u00a0al.\u2019s system #12, however, the bulk of the source galaxy image projected as Hamilton\u2019s Object is not bisected by the corresponding critical curve. The critical curve runs alongside the outskirts of the galaxy, and through an outer spiral arm \u2013 see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>HST</em> observations of this field were taken over a time span of 3\u00a0yr (2013\u22122016). There were no discernible changes to the images, in contrast with system #12a in Caminha et\u00a0al.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Nevertheless, Hamilton\u2019s Object may be one of the few additional candidates, thus far, for the potential future observation of microlensing of individual stars on the critical line of a cluster of galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Caminha et\u00a0al.\u2019s system #12, the critical line for z =\u00a00.94 bisects the folded galaxy image (fig. 1 of Kaurov, reproduced here as Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>) and almost happens to coincide with the isodensity contour for 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>15</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22122</sup>, shown as the white line in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. There should then be a third, sometimes called a \u2018counterimage\u2019, which is identified as object #12a of Caminha et\u00a0al. Unfortunately, this image is on the northern side of a large, unassociated galaxy (Caminha et\u00a0al. fig. A1) and may be partly confused with the outer spiral arm of that galaxy, but the MUSE imaging/spectroscopy shows that it is a separate object. This third image shows that the source object is a clumpy irregular galaxy. Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) did not have access to the spectroscopic MUSE data of Caminha et\u00a0al., but one of their two guesses for the counterimage was later confirmed; lacking spectroscopic data, however, their attempted modelling for this lens is a rather poor fit to the data. Due to the very elongated nature of the cluster mass distribution in MACS J0416.1-2403 (Richard et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, their fig. 4), many or all lensed systems appear as triply imaged configurations (e.g. systems #4,\u00a0#5,\u00a0#7,\u00a0#13,\u00a0and #16 in Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), but system #12 summarized above may be one of the few systems on the critical line for its redshift. All of the lensed systems have been used jointly to determine the mass distribution in MACS J0416.1-2404 (Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Grillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) using the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> software developed by Julio et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) or other software packages.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Other examples of gravitational folds and cusps include the VLT/MUSE Deeply Lensed Field where a Lyman-\u03b1 emitter at z \u00a0=\u00a06.6 has been found by Vanzella et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) and is also on a critical line for its redshift. Further examples of triple systems can be found in RELICS (Cerny et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Coe et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). A more extreme example, with a background galaxy lensed into an Einstein ring by a cluster, is that of Abell 3827 (Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>) where the authors show that DM is required over any alternative gravitational conjecture.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103536 id=\"269103536\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 The candidate counterimage</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">By comparison with the above observations of lensed systems in MACS J0416.1-2403 and other observations of similar systems (e.g. the folded lensed object in galaxy cluster MACS J1149.5\u00a0+\u00a02223; Wagner\u00a0&amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a> (WB16), their fig. 4), together with simulations (Wagner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) there should be a third or \u2018counterimage\u2019 thrown off roughly in the direction of the elongation of the stretched clumps and towards the lens centre, where the latter has not been determined by the photometric surveys or any other method. The simulation by Wagner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, fig. 4), however, shows that the lens centre is on the opposite side of the critical line to the more \u2018splayed out\u2019 or distorted part of the folded images, despite the simplicity of the simulation. We note that the southern part of Hamilton\u2019s Object is the more splayed; so the lens centre, as well as the third or counterimage, can be expected to be found on the northern side of the two folded images. Further, by comparison with the lensed system in MACS J1149.5\u00a0+\u00a02223 (Wagner\u00a0&amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, fig. 4) and also with system #12a of Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we might expect to find the third or counterimage of Hamilton\u2019s Object at a distance from the critical line of about 5 to 10 times the angular distance between the two nuclear bulge components of the folded pair, which are separated by 2.6 arcsec (e.g. Narayan\u00a0&amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>, Wagner\u00a0&amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on position, colours, and morphology, we thus identified a candidate third or \u2018counterimage\u2019 as <em>C</em> \u00a0in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, a \u2018clumpy\u2019 disc galaxy seen nearly edge-on. We know rather little about the cluster morphology, however (see Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), so it might be that the cluster is an elongated merger similar to those mentioned above. A Singular Isothermal Ellipsoid would lead to a fourth image on the other side of the cluster centre, and we have an unconfirmed candidate for that, but further observations are required (we assume here that the galaxy marked <em>RM</em> in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> is not at the cluster centre).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The nucleus and clumpy galaxy are lensed into a \u2018fold\u2019 configuration straddling the critical line in the lens plane, and the components are therefore stretched in a direction roughly orthogonal to the critical line (e.g. WB16), in the same way as objects #12 b, c of Caminha et\u00a0al. in EMACS J0416.1-2403, or the folds in the cluster SDSS J1226\u00a0+\u00a02152 (Dai et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). The stretched arcs are formed as two images of the source galaxy merge at the position of the critical curve, which results in the mirror-symmetric appearance. The magnified arcs constrain the local position and shape of the critical curve, as shown below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The relaxation state of the galaxy cluster RM223013.1-080853.1 has not been determined yet, and Hamilton\u2019s Object may be the result of an ellipsoidal mass-density profile or of a merger structure like EMACSJ046.1. In both configurations, a third counterimage is expected north of Hamilton\u2019s Object as detailed previously. The direction of \u2018stretch\u2019 or elongation in the outer (east and west) lensed components is not orthogonal to the apparent line of symmetry or critical line (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). In fact, the direction of elongation is at an angle of about 20 deg. to the orthogonal to the line of symmetry or critical line. This rules out a simple Navarro-Frenk-White (NFW, Navarro, Frenk\u00a0&amp; White <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) radial mass profile for the cluster (Wagner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), in favour of an ellipsoidal profile more consistent with the observed (irregular) galaxy distribution (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> below, we show via detailed simulations that the NFW profile is ruled out. In the massive cluster MACSJ0416.1-2403, the isodensity contours are very elongated, because the cluster is the merger of two large sub-clusters, and system #12 of Caminha et\u00a0al. and other systems lensed there are close to the very elongated critical line (see fig. 4 of Caminha et al).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Prior to the spectroscopic observations described below, we had thus identified a candidate counterpart for the third or counter-image as a large disc-like \u2018clumpy\u2019 galaxy at RA 22<sup>h</sup>30<sup>m</sup>9<sup>s</sup>.45, Dec. \u22128\u00b09\u203220\u2033.6 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, object <em>C</em>), with a nuclear bulge of magnitude 23.7 (in <em>HST</em> ACS/F606W, possibly confused with circumnuclear emission). Object <em>C</em> is fainter relative to objects <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> as expected (<em>A</em> has nuclear bulge mag. 23.2 in F606W, and <em>B</em> has mag. 22.8). This candidature was based on the colour, morphology, and astrometry of the counterimage candidate <em>C</em> components in both visible and the infrared bands: the characteristics were matched with components of the lensed images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> in both bands. The nuclear bulge and \u2018clumps\u2019 in image <em>C</em> are stretched radially in lensed objects <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. In addition, <em>C</em> has an arc-like feature to the NW of the nuclear bulge and this appears, folded, between and to the west of bulge images <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, and the two \u2018mirrored\u2019 faint arcs meet close to the critical line. The faint arc-like feature is interpreted as a spiral arm of the disc seen at low inclination (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). In image <em>B</em>, the parity is \u2018positive\u2019 (even); in image <em>A</em>, the parity is negative or odd, i.e. the counterimage <em>C</em> is flipped around an E-W axis roughly parallel to the critical line.</p>                        <a id=\"269103546\" scrollto-destination=\"269103546\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=u2YaSSvrSu0VHS8FiWZwV7~uBoNy1X0GZbpAX4nISRylj5yjkc3Xu5vuy4D-kkPeaFnXlT8hBN9Drrp3GjdRmOz1Fv14iHVd6k8A3UQ4xWiATMhTUUNLa00I5~vBJIbt1TUuzM8wKCEPlWjsHyNsblbxw1PJI7RyZeGIwKrD3-VuwixaMINUCXdYDzDxr8t9B1WpBx7V5mxvduV5OrJ3LvG-2q7bN0MFoSYMkr7TAhCIs1UwVw3FrJH38OdONeLbUU2chmbjgS5HmQ60-Sv7SpQxJRHkVYkBys7tTlKo5zcH4-Od4J7bYbLYyVDnCgS6F47IESGSgGUwMUINj7a21Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The contrast-stretched F110W HST image of \u2018counterimage\u2019 C, showing feature 7 on the edge of the galaxy, which is approximately 4 arcsec across. Feature 1 is the nuclear bulge, and features 2 through 6 are also shown in Figs\u00a012 and\u00a014. The contrast has been stretched such that noise is visible at low levels.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103546/stab1375fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103546\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=0rkKPfdmBRIwGWWwTs6YguQ-lzVS8GsJZq~5wOB5L8ubeVPsB1CTwM~2tT8j1il1Y1ewH5znzq-I3lpkQL8s-qYrHfVo8br~x0Z~8h7cfsInJ8ZBd4k02AjCLuk3FgJlxaHFzbmGmO-Li4np0DuSVXjYOSZ69osXgdxrobJw78tDxhfZ~WHoqmMYRUu-JdzMSVcbXRCVNUHmcg5qvU4RcCPvC4tKDC8fWaZ2OM2GHMbGvaTcOYCuBfw~23UXJsx61iIsOEZdTtnMj7Iwwjh10A5HOPTHrKTr67A8iV~4GW5mYQY8TtPvHiN9-B8CP4r5Kdplz-cDfC24KWMIFLl4Qw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103546&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The contrast-stretched F110W <em>HST</em> image of \u2018counterimage\u2019 <em>C</em>, showing feature 7 on the edge of the galaxy, which is approximately 4 arcsec across. Feature 1 is the nuclear bulge, and features 2 through 6 are also shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a>. The contrast has been stretched such that noise is visible at low levels.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=u2YaSSvrSu0VHS8FiWZwV7~uBoNy1X0GZbpAX4nISRylj5yjkc3Xu5vuy4D-kkPeaFnXlT8hBN9Drrp3GjdRmOz1Fv14iHVd6k8A3UQ4xWiATMhTUUNLa00I5~vBJIbt1TUuzM8wKCEPlWjsHyNsblbxw1PJI7RyZeGIwKrD3-VuwixaMINUCXdYDzDxr8t9B1WpBx7V5mxvduV5OrJ3LvG-2q7bN0MFoSYMkr7TAhCIs1UwVw3FrJH38OdONeLbUU2chmbjgS5HmQ60-Sv7SpQxJRHkVYkBys7tTlKo5zcH4-Od4J7bYbLYyVDnCgS6F47IESGSgGUwMUINj7a21Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The contrast-stretched F110W HST image of \u2018counterimage\u2019 C, showing feature 7 on the edge of the galaxy, which is approximately 4 arcsec across. Feature 1 is the nuclear bulge, and features 2 through 6 are also shown in Figs\u00a012 and\u00a014. The contrast has been stretched such that noise is visible at low levels.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/269103546/stab1375fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"269103546\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/stab1375fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&Signature=0rkKPfdmBRIwGWWwTs6YguQ-lzVS8GsJZq~5wOB5L8ubeVPsB1CTwM~2tT8j1il1Y1ewH5znzq-I3lpkQL8s-qYrHfVo8br~x0Z~8h7cfsInJ8ZBd4k02AjCLuk3FgJlxaHFzbmGmO-Li4np0DuSVXjYOSZ69osXgdxrobJw78tDxhfZ~WHoqmMYRUu-JdzMSVcbXRCVNUHmcg5qvU4RcCPvC4tKDC8fWaZ2OM2GHMbGvaTcOYCuBfw~23UXJsx61iIsOEZdTtnMj7Iwwjh10A5HOPTHrKTr67A8iV~4GW5mYQY8TtPvHiN9-B8CP4r5Kdplz-cDfC24KWMIFLl4Qw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=269103546&ar=6276726&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1375fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The contrast-stretched F110W <em>HST</em> image of \u2018counterimage\u2019 <em>C</em>, showing feature 7 on the edge of the galaxy, which is approximately 4 arcsec across. Feature 1 is the nuclear bulge, and features 2 through 6 are also shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a>. The contrast has been stretched such that noise is visible at low levels.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the <em>HST</em> F606W images, the morphology and astrometry of the many components in candidate <em>C</em> clearly match the folded and stretched morphologies of the components in <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. It is not immediately obvious that the compact object labelled C7 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> is physically associated with galaxy <em>C</em>, but a stretched-contrast image of the galaxy in F110W (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>) makes this association extremely likely, and the object may be an outlying superstarcluster. In this case, the counterimage outlying object C7 appears as objects A7 and B7 in the folded images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With regard to the nature of the source galaxy, we note that there are no shortages of \u2018clumpy\u2019 or \u2018chain\u2019 galaxies at moderate-to-high redshifts, as shown from many <em>HST</em> surveys (e.g. <em>HST</em> Medium Deep Survey: Naim, Ratnatunga\u00a0&amp; Griffiths (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>), Abraham et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>); \u2018Chain Galaxies\u2019 (Cowie, Hu\u00a0&amp; Songaila <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>), Buta (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>); the HDF: van den Bergh et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), Elmegreen, Elmegreen\u00a0&amp; Sheets (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>); GOODS: Elmegreen\u00a0&amp; Elmegreen (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), Elmegreen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>); COSMOS: Scarlata et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>); CANDELS: Peth et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>); Lotz, Primack\u00a0&amp; Madau (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). It has been shown that \u2018chain\u2019 or stringy galaxies are usually clumpy disc-like galaxies seen at low inclination angles (e.g. Dalcanton\u00a0&amp; Shectman <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; see also Elmegreen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>) and this is apparently the case here. By stretching the contrast of the <em>HST</em> archival images (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>), we note that <em>C</em> is a clumpy disc galaxy seen at low inclination, with a bright nuclear bulge. The overall angular size of image <em>C</em> is at least 4 arcsec, corresponding to 30\u00a0kpc at a redshift of 0.82 (from Ned Wright: Cosmology Calculator I, <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0= 69.6, \u03a9<sub><em>M</em></sub>\u00a0= 0.286, flat universe). This is, of course, the apparent size after magnification and distortion by the cluster lens.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Having established the clear candidature of galaxy <em>C</em> as the counterimage, spectroscopy was performed as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.3</a> below, confirming it. The counterimage <em>C</em> is the image best representing the morphology of the background source because it is apparently the least distorted image.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=269103568 id=\"269103568\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Optical spectroscopy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The lensed and folded nuclear bulge objects <em>A</em>1 and <em>B</em>1 were observed on 2018 September 7, using the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph GMOS-N (an integral field unit [IFU]) in long-slit mode (for a description of GMOS-N, see Allington-Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) and Hook et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)). The observations used the GG455 filter and the R150 grating disperser centred at 680\u2009nm with the red-sensitive, fully depleted Hamamatsu CCDs (the same as those installed in GMOS-S \u2013 see Gimeno et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>)), having a plate scale of 0.0807 arcsec per pixel. Exposure times were of duration 900 s and the total integration time was 1.5\u00a0h. The resulting summed spectrum of nuclear bulge images <em>A</em>1 and <em>B</em>1 is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>; although the spectrum is of rather low signal to noise, some features are clearly visible, as summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We identify O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> \u03bb\u00a03727\u00c5, the Ca\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> H&amp;K break at \u03bb 4000\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0 and CN absorption at \u03bb \u2243 4180 \u00c5, giving a tentative redshift of 0.82. The long-slit observation did not include counterimage <em>C</em>, and prior observations in 2017 using GMOS-N in full IFU mode did not result in good data because of poor observing conditions.</p> \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>3727\u00a0</td><td>4000\u00a0</td><td>4180\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Observed \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>6783\u00a0</td><td>7280\u00a0</td><td>7608\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Ion\u00a0</td><td>O\u2009<span \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>3727\u00a0</td><td>4000\u00a0</td><td>4180\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Observed \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>6783\u00a0</td><td>7280\u00a0</td><td>7608\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/269103591\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectral lines from Gemini GMOS-N data: Objects <em>A</em>1, <em>B</em>1 only.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Ion\u00a0</td><td>O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>Ca\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> H&amp;K\u00a0</td><td>CN\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Rest \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>3727\u00a0</td><td>4000\u00a0</td><td>4180\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Observed \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>6783\u00a0</td><td>7280\u00a0</td><td>7608\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Ion\u00a0</td><td>O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>Ca\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> H&amp;K\u00a0</td><td>CN\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Rest \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>3727\u00a0</td><td>4000\u00a0</td><td>4180\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Observed \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>6783\u00a0</td><td>7280\u00a0</td><td>7608\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/269103591\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Keck Cosmic Web Imager (KCWI; see Morrissey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) is an IFU that was used at the right Nasmyth focus of the <em>Keck II</em> telescope to make observations of the lensed images on 2020 September 16 UT. The field included all identified lensed components <em>A</em>,\u00a0<em>B</em>, and <em>C</em>. The Blue KCWI was used with the \u2018large\u2019 8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a022 arcsec. field of view, with the grating centred at 4500\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0and no red (blocking) filter. The long dimension of the IFU was oriented N-S so that objects <em>A</em>,\u00a0<em>B</em>, and <em>C</em> were covered by a single field, which was observed over 3\u00a0h with individual exposures of 900\u2009s each, in atmospheric seeing that was typically 0.3 arcsec The effective spectral coverage extended from 3600\u00a0to 5600\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0 \u2013 this was not optimal for an object at a suspected moderate redshift, but was used for schedule and programmatic reasons. Spectra of the main (nuclear bulge) components <em>A</em>1, <em>B</em>1, and <em>C</em>1 are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, and the absorption line identifications are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The most useful spectral features in the rest-frame NUV are the resonant absorption lines from the low-ionization species Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, and O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> in the interstellar medium and/or circumgalactic medium (Zhu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The compilation of absorption line indices in the ultraviolet by Maraston et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) is also very useful in the identification of NUV absorption lines. All three nuclear bulge images <em>A</em>1, <em>B</em>1, <em>C</em>1 show four strong absorption lines longward of 5000\u2009\u00c5, confirming galaxy <em>C</em> as the \u2018counterimage\u2019 to the folded objects <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. The MgI doublet 2800\u2009\u00c5\u00a0 absorption shows a blue wing, perhaps indicative of ouflowing gas from the star-forming nuclear bulge, in common with this same feature found in many or all large star-forming spiral galaxies at slightly higher redshift, with outflows of typically several hundred and up to 1000\u00a0km s<sup>\u22121</sup> (Wiener et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). This broad absorption feature may also include discrete absorption lines of Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>. Shortward of 5000\u2009\u00c5, additional absorption lines observed in <em>A</em>1, <em>B</em>1, and <em>C</em>1 include several lines from Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> etc. (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), but the spectrum of nuclear bulge <em>C</em>1 is noisy in this region. For the gravitationally magnified images <em>A</em>1 and <em>B</em>1, a smaller aperture was used to isolate the nuclear bulge spectrum using SAO-IMAGE DS9; this is more difficult for the counterimage nuclear bulge <em>C</em>1, where a larger aperture is needed for better signal to noise, so the continuum is not a good match to those of <em>A</em>1 and <em>B</em>1 at all wavelengths. The spectra also show that the counterimage galaxy, a large spiral with a compact nuclear bulge, has absorption lines found in some Seyfert galaxies and LINERS (Low Ionization Nuclear Emission Line galaxies), as noted in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, along with outflowing gas.</p>                        <a id=\"269103593\" scrollto-destination=\"269103593\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/506/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1375/1/m_stab1375fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639081231&amp;Signature=vTXXF4IF7ABuNVybgtqI25nY4LKhM~AKF9CFdaLmD-D6pDrXNFOIG4hcynf-PPqh5f0dAc7sh2V3BjtWkp0-dRlYUz-~S2C120slXVoQCC9sdVPA9S0g1waI9d~W4ZGisCIJlna8vt7hCVZC7qYZYcllAVm4y4Nc41D66rgChxPPzjNvkAc71ROSB3QhgZyecukQ~JYe4Mii2qwY9V1BPXOlPlt0Iz95xIRroINdD5g9xe-aAiohXLTz1JhPs1lKbq5euT5UjD96pS8fyS7DsBIfLzy~J33L0UyHr6uxP4GsZ6fNm0T~kfSQRjICQjp8PtxvDIxxRx3u8Z9bjUP-Rw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"KCWI spectra of the nuclear bulge images A1, B1, and C1 in Fig.\u00a02. \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>2249\u00a0</td><td>2261\u00a0</td><td>2280\u00a0</td><td>2326\u00a0</td><td>2343\u00a0</td><td>2365\u00a0</td><td>2383\u00a0</td><td>2451\u00a0</td><td>2459\u00a0</td><td>2609\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Observed \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>4094\u00a0</td><td>4115\u00a0</td><td>4150\u00a0</td><td>4230\u00a0</td><td>4265\u00a0</td><td>4305\u00a0</td><td>4350\u00a0</td><td>4460\u00a0</td><td>4476\u00a0</td><td>4747\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Objects<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Ion\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>*\u00a0</td><td>C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Rest \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>2249\u00a0</td><td>2261\u00a0</td><td>2280\u00a0</td><td>2326\u00a0</td><td>2343\u00a0</td><td>2365\u00a0</td><td>2383\u00a0</td><td>2451\u00a0</td><td>2459\u00a0</td><td>2609\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Observed \u03bb \u00c5\u00a0</td><td>4094\u00a0</td><td>4115\u00a0</td><td>4150\u00a0</td><td>4230\u00a0</td><td>4265\u00a0</td><td>4305\u00a0</td><td>4350\u00a0</td><td>4460\u00a0</td><td>4476\u00a0</td><td>4747\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div        </a></div></div></div>                        <a id=\"269103599\" scrollto-destination=\"269103599\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"utbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div \u00c5.\u00a0</td><td>2676\u00a0</td><td>2712\u00a0</td><td>2753\u00a0</td><td>2766\u00a0</td><td>2796\u00a0</td><td>2803\u00a0</td><td>2905\u00a0</td><td>3004\u00a0</td><td>3007\u00a0</td><td>3074\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Observed (a) as in MCG 8-11-11 (Ulrich et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Ion\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> (doublet)\u00a0</td><td>Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>
